number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												VERDICT: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a well-made game that provides a good if quite not complete simulation of jigsaw puzzle-solving on a PC. There are a good number of puzzles to solve, with a fair variety of pictures. Each one using a nice mix of colours and joins to keep the challenge fresh and the puzzle-solving experience interesting.  While the learning curve may about right for casual players the overall difficulty is pretty easy. Even the hardest puzzle is just a question of applying time, patience and perseverance to reach the final solution. Probably the only thing missing is that pieces cannot be rotated which though significant isnt really an issue.I enjoyed it. Its not my sort of usual game but its relaxing enough to while away some time between larger more complex or action-oriented games. If you have ever received a physical jigsaw puzzle and enjoy solving them then you will enjoy the challenge the game provides even if it is not a complete representation. If you have never tried solving puzzles in real-life then this may be ideal for you to try and see if you like it.... More info below ...01. GENRE: Casual Jigsaw Puzzle Simulation.02. SETTING: Japan themed pictures.03. STORY/BACKGROUND: n/a.04. GAME MODES: Single-player. As its name implies the game allows you to play (make) twenty-one unique jigsaw puzzles of various sizes and difficulty, with themed pictures from one of my favourite cultures - Japan. Smaller puzzles those with fewer pieces must be completed in order to progress to harder ones those with more pieces.05. GAME/LEVEL DESIGN: Overall the design is spartan with the only focus being to complete the puzzle. The makers have included almost all the few facets required to keep jigsaw-puzzle solving great fun and the range of pictures ensures boredom wont set in. 06. GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS: The aim is of course easy enough.  Rearrange the pieces to complete the original picture.  Playing pieces are cut differently between most pictures. You can call upon a picture reveal feature to receive hints in-game. Different joint designs ensure that players will not get used to one style of grooves which keeps playing fresh. There is no mid-game saving unfortunately. Which is not a problem with the smaller puzzles but if you want to take a break during an attempt on the larger puzzles you will need to complete it or restart from scratch.Pieces of the jigsaw cannot be rotated, so this makes solving them a little easier. Even if the addition of a 'stream' to keep the pieces moving was added to replace this, it makes picking up pieces that much more fiddly. To the point that it becomes fairly annoying when after five or sixe tries on the larger puzzles, you cannot pick up the piece you want.07. ENEMIES: N/a.08. A.I: N/a.09. CONTROLS: Mostly its a question of mouse-driven point and drag. Letting go where you wish to place the current selected piece. Moving the cursor over the piece that you wish to select isnt as straightforward as you would imagine. Especially with the constant movement of all pieces in the stream. Though strangely, this seems to be an intended 'feature' not a bug. Likely something to replace the lack of rotating pieces which you would get in RL.  At least when a piece is dropped there is a nice sounds to inform players that it has been placed on its correct position.10. GRAPHICS: Decent well-drawn/computerized pictures and portraits of Japanese themed subjects. Nothing amazing but more than adequate. 11. SOUNDTRACK & AUDIO: A melodic Japanese themed score that chimes along at an apt rate in keeping with the slow methodical way in which many players (I expect) will be attempting to solve their puzzles.12. VOICE ACTING: N/a.13. CHALLENGE/DIFFICULTY: Fairly easy. Especially the first few puzzles. There are a few harder ones providing more of a challenge later in the game.  Plus the variation in joint design adds to the problem solving as progress is made.14. PROBLEMS: Picking up intended pieces as they are constantly moving in the stream. Though as explained this likely a feature with a non-pinpoint mouse cursor. I was also unable to capture screenshots using the Steam overlay.15. ACHIEVEMENTS: Easy to complete. Almost all are triggered on solved the puzzles available in game. A further two are quick fun interface achievements.16. DLC: None. There are other games in the series that use other themes if you want more of the same.17. MODDING/ONLINE PLAY/COMMUNITY: N/a18. ENJOYMENT/APPEAL: Anyone who like solving jigsaw puzzles and has a computer will enjoy it. Bonus if you like all things Japan.  IF you are a lover of hardcore or action games you may best our time on other games!19. PLAYTIME/LONGEVITY/REPLAYABILITY: I suppose if you dont mind replaying the puzzles over and over you could potentially play this infinitely or at least many many times. Otherwise there is a good 10h+ if you are just happy to play through each puzzle once and only once.20. VALUE FOR MONEY: Great on a sale. I wouldnt necessary recommend it at full price though it depends, on how many times you intend to replay the puzzles. Personally I don't feel the retail price offers value for money unless you aim to replay the puzzles every so often. As this is the first in the series unless you are put off by the Japanese theme or prefer one of the other titles (Zombie, Birds or Anime...) I suggest you pick this up in a a sale.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Simple jigsaw puzzle game that somehow gets it wrong.I like both digital and physical jigsaw puzzles. I'm not spectacular at them or anything but I enjoy them. Guess I'm a boring dude! Needless to say I figured this game would occupy me for a few hours and be worth the trade I made for it. But it suffers from a some flaws. The difficulty curve is non-existent; Beyond piece count increasing there's no challenge. There is no piece rotation so each piece is always in it's correct orientation. Then the way some puzzles are "cut" the pieces are TOO unique and spotting a pair is a breeze. Pieces lock to their place on the board so any time you're stuck you can drag and drop around until you get "lucky" if you're really determined to get rid of a piece. But pieces will not lock to each other freely outside of their spot on the board, so there's no putting together a few pieces out of place and moving them all together into place later.Interaction and interface is um weird;You have your build space but no open space to pre-build (not that you can anyway like mentioned above). All the "loose" pieces are floating in a upside-down L-shaped koi pond and they are constantly floating around and moving. And there, I swear to you, lurks a little gremlin of monumental proportions! And it isn't the koi fish... You can't see him but I swear to you he is there. No matter what. I dunno how the game does it. But no matter what. The piece you want to click to pick up will NEVER be the piece you want if there's another piece remotely close. It is absolutely uncanny. I actually get excited when I get a piece I was actually trying to snag, that's how rarely it happens. I thought it was just with edges, that it didn't like edge pieces, but nope. There's a effin' gremlin in there mocking me and making my mouse click pick up anything but the piece I want. This issue gets more and more ridiculous as the amount of pieces increases. The koi pond stays the same size and more and more pieces go in it as you get to later puzzles. pieces will begin to overlap four or more deep in later puzzles. And the gremlin will just laugh at you. Then there's the normal small dev team stuff you could normally overlook;-Puzzle pieces in the koi pond are much smaller than on the board creating visual discrepancies.-When you "drop" a piece back to the pond it doesn't go where you drop it, it goes to a specific starting point in the middle of the action. So you cannot attempt any organization of pieces. -Sound settings made in main menu don't save to in-game. I wanted music off and SFX on. But then in-game its just everything off or everything on. -Messed with windows 10 title bars when played fullscreen and minimized to desktop.-Always launches in fullscreen even if you switched to windowed last play.-No saving mid-puzzle. -Etc.Just can't recommend it. At any price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												VERDICT: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a well-made game that provides a good if quite not complete simulation of jigsaw puzzle-solving on a PC. There are a good number of puzzles to solve, with a fair variety of pictures. Each one using a nice mix of colours and joins to keep the challenge fresh and the puzzle-solving experience interesting.  While the learning curve may about right for casual players the overall difficulty is pretty easy. Even the hardest puzzle is just a question of applying time, patience and perseverance to reach the final solution. Probably the only thing missing is that pieces cannot be rotated which though significant isnt really an issue.I enjoyed it. Its not my sort of usual game but its relaxing enough to while away some time between larger more complex or action-oriented games. If you have ever received a physical jigsaw puzzle and enjoy solving them then you will enjoy the challenge the game provides even if it is not a complete representation. If you have never tried solving puzzles in real-life then this may be ideal for you to try and see if you like it.... More info below ...01. GENRE: Casual Jigsaw Puzzle Simulation.02. SETTING: Japan themed pictures.03. STORY/BACKGROUND: n/a.04. GAME MODES: Single-player. As its name implies the game allows you to play (make) twenty-one unique jigsaw puzzles of various sizes and difficulty, with themed pictures from one of my favourite cultures - Japan. Smaller puzzles those with fewer pieces must be completed in order to progress to harder ones those with more pieces.05. GAME/LEVEL DESIGN: Overall the design is spartan with the only focus being to complete the puzzle. The makers have included almost all the few facets required to keep jigsaw-puzzle solving great fun and the range of pictures ensures boredom wont set in. 06. GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS: The aim is of course easy enough.  Rearrange the pieces to complete the original picture.  Playing pieces are cut differently between most pictures. You can call upon a picture reveal feature to receive hints in-game. Different joint designs ensure that players will not get used to one style of grooves which keeps playing fresh. There is no mid-game saving unfortunately. Which is not a problem with the smaller puzzles but if you want to take a break during an attempt on the larger puzzles you will need to complete it or restart from scratch.Pieces of the jigsaw cannot be rotated, so this makes solving them a little easier. Even if the addition of a 'stream' to keep the pieces moving was added to replace this, it makes picking up pieces that much more fiddly. To the point that it becomes fairly annoying when after five or sixe tries on the larger puzzles, you cannot pick up the piece you want.07. ENEMIES: N/a.08. A.I: N/a.09. CONTROLS: Mostly its a question of mouse-driven point and drag. Letting go where you wish to place the current selected piece. Moving the cursor over the piece that you wish to select isnt as straightforward as you would imagine. Especially with the constant movement of all pieces in the stream. Though strangely, this seems to be an intended 'feature' not a bug. Likely something to replace the lack of rotating pieces which you would get in RL.  At least when a piece is dropped there is a nice sounds to inform players that it has been placed on its correct position.10. GRAPHICS: Decent well-drawn/computerized pictures and portraits of Japanese themed subjects. Nothing amazing but more than adequate. 11. SOUNDTRACK & AUDIO: A melodic Japanese themed score that chimes along at an apt rate in keeping with the slow methodical way in which many players (I expect) will be attempting to solve their puzzles.12. VOICE ACTING: N/a.13. CHALLENGE/DIFFICULTY: Fairly easy. Especially the first few puzzles. There are a few harder ones providing more of a challenge later in the game.  Plus the variation in joint design adds to the problem solving as progress is made.14. PROBLEMS: Picking up intended pieces as they are constantly moving in the stream. Though as explained this likely a feature with a non-pinpoint mouse cursor. I was also unable to capture screenshots using the Steam overlay.15. ACHIEVEMENTS: Easy to complete. Almost all are triggered on solved the puzzles available in game. A further two are quick fun interface achievements.16. DLC: None. There are other games in the series that use other themes if you want more of the same.17. MODDING/ONLINE PLAY/COMMUNITY: N/a18. ENJOYMENT/APPEAL: Anyone who like solving jigsaw puzzles and has a computer will enjoy it. Bonus if you like all things Japan.  IF you are a lover of hardcore or action games you may best our time on other games!19. PLAYTIME/LONGEVITY/REPLAYABILITY: I suppose if you dont mind replaying the puzzles over and over you could potentially play this infinitely or at least many many times. Otherwise there is a good 10h+ if you are just happy to play through each puzzle once and only once.20. VALUE FOR MONEY: Great on a sale. I wouldnt necessary recommend it at full price though it depends, on how many times you intend to replay the puzzles. Personally I don't feel the retail price offers value for money unless you aim to replay the puzzles every so often. As this is the first in the series unless you are put off by the Japanese theme or prefer one of the other titles (Zombie, Birds or Anime...) I suggest you pick this up in a a sale.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Computer puzzle games have been around for a long while – well as far as I can remember. My earliest knowledge is called ‘European Scene Jigsaw Puzzles Vol. 1’ by Thorn EMI UK way back in 1981.  A nice game with crisp graphics amid the moderate choice of colours, it served its purpose. Fast forward to April 2014, another puzzle game caught my attention which happens to be in the form of this review – Pixel Puzzles: Japan. What attracted me to this game is the theme (Japan) that plays upon the ‘traditional’ puzzle gameplay. Well, once I have knocked out all the puzzles, this puzzle game leaves a lot to be desired.So let’s start off with the good points first. This puzzle game certainly does have a traditional Japanese feel with the puzzle borders filled with water and floating Lilly pads – that is the Koi Pond. Also there’s a carp swimming about where you can actually can catch it. Place the carp on the puzzle board and he’ll fishtail back (excuse the pun) to the pond. There are other things you can do to the carp however I let you discover it (and no, you cannot eat it).There are nineteen puzzles to choose from and the pieces range from sixty to the granddaddy three hundred and fifty. I guess the puzzle purists won’t considering three hundred and fifty large however, in this game, it’s the largest. The puzzle pieces are not your ‘traditional’ piece as most have weird shapes to them. In addition to this, you cannot refer to the puzzle picture at all as there’s an additional ‘feature’ where you need to unlock - the ‘Power of the I-Ching’.The way this works is that there’s a golden ‘Yin Yang’ piece randomly placed in the puzzle. Once you place the piece on the random placement, you unlock one part of the I-Ching. Do this eight times you can use its power. The power is the reveal the actual picture for a short moment or two and that’s about it. Talking about a buzz killer aye. I guess the developers needs something ‘authentic’ to enhance this game.And now here comes the unpleasant parts. First thing is this I-Ching concept – personally it’s just a waste of feature as the puzzles are all quite easy to do. Granted some are a little difficult however for me, the I-Ching is just a gimmick that can do without. Secondly, you can go crazily clicking on every part of the canvas until the piece slots in as there’s no penalty to do so. Also, because the game forces the pieces to slot in nicely, it takes away the fun of building ‘mini canvases’ all over the board.Third, you cannot rotate the pieces so every piece is the right way up so it’s making this easy puzzle game even easier to play. Fourth, there’s no save feature so you cannot park the puzzle to take a little rest and fifth, there’s a bug where, when you try to grab a puzzle piece from the pond, there’s a good chance that you will select another piece close to it instead of the one you have chosen. I think the reason behind this is the puzzle's algorithm. It’s designed that, if there’s a couple of pieces bunched up together, the algorithm selects the piece that represents the north western corner of the picture first and finally, south eastern corner last.Yet there’s two more that really grips me the most. The first being the quality of all the pictures. I presume they are the developer's photos however, all the pictures are extremely low quality. This is an absolute no-no as, being a puzzle game, its primary objective is to provide the user high quality pictures. The second is the abysmal sounds – the background music is nothing more than a short musical scores that loops over and over again. Also the sound quality, just like the photos are abysmal – very low quality; so low you can even hear the hissing sound. At least they could have bought a decent microphone or maybe remove the hissing sound from the original recording.Other than completing the puzzles, there’s an extra feature where you can view the gallery and see who made this game (without the dart board). There’s also two additional puzzles to complete at any time as, I believe are the free DLC for this game – another words, you don’t have to unlock them. So being a ‘traditional’ puzzle game is nothing more than a farce. With so many negatives, it’s a wonder why I completed all the puzzles. Actually the main reason why I did is because of the achievements. If there wasn’t any, this puzzle game will be ditched straight into the bin, figuratively speaking.3 / 10

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
A jigsaw puzzle game where you can't do many of the things you would likely do when putting together a physical jigsaw puzzle.First off, when tweaking with the options setting such as changing from fullscreen to window (no resolution options available), music, and sound effects, none of the settings stay the same when you start the game up again; you'd have to retweak all that stuff to their desired place. The options menu itself doesn't really contain all that much anyway.Puzzle pieces can't be rotated but are apparently already turned the right way so there'd be no need for that.You can't piece together matching jigsaw puzzles; each individual piece can only be snapped on the canvas where they belong even if there are no other pieces around. This means that you can basically grab a puzzle piece and keep dragging & dropping the thing all over the canvas, if desired, until it snaps into the place where it's apparently supposed to go.The puzzle pieces you're supposed to grab outside of the canvas don't stay still; they slowly float about on a pond outside of the field bouncing from walls, a few sometimes get stuck on a wall and just stay still for whatever reason. It becomes more of a bother than a challenge (if it's even supposed to be a challenge of some kind) since the pieces will always overlap one another, so way too likely you won't always grab the puzzle piece you want even if the mouse is on the desired piece. This is much worse later on when the pieces become smaller and higher in number. You can drag the puzzle pieces out of the pond to the canvas but that's more than likely to just block the view of the canvas itself with clutter.If you were to leave a puzzle-in-progress it doesn't save and there's no option to. If you need to exit the game you'd have to start whatever puzzle you were doing all over again.I was hoping this jigsaw puzzle game was more of the things I'd do with a pyshical one and not just a game where I just drag piece (A) to point (B) with the addition of technical nuisances.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Simple jigsaw puzzle game that somehow gets it wrong.I like both digital and physical jigsaw puzzles. I'm not spectacular at them or anything but I enjoy them. Guess I'm a boring dude! Needless to say I figured this game would occupy me for a few hours and be worth the trade I made for it. But it suffers from a some flaws. The difficulty curve is non-existent; Beyond piece count increasing there's no challenge. There is no piece rotation so each piece is always in it's correct orientation. Then the way some puzzles are "cut" the pieces are TOO unique and spotting a pair is a breeze. Pieces lock to their place on the board so any time you're stuck you can drag and drop around until you get "lucky" if you're really determined to get rid of a piece. But pieces will not lock to each other freely outside of their spot on the board, so there's no putting together a few pieces out of place and moving them all together into place later.Interaction and interface is um weird;You have your build space but no open space to pre-build (not that you can anyway like mentioned above). All the "loose" pieces are floating in a upside-down L-shaped koi pond and they are constantly floating around and moving. And there, I swear to you, lurks a little gremlin of monumental proportions! And it isn't the koi fish... You can't see him but I swear to you he is there. No matter what. I dunno how the game does it. But no matter what. The piece you want to click to pick up will NEVER be the piece you want if there's another piece remotely close. It is absolutely uncanny. I actually get excited when I get a piece I was actually trying to snag, that's how rarely it happens. I thought it was just with edges, that it didn't like edge pieces, but nope. There's a effin' gremlin in there mocking me and making my mouse click pick up anything but the piece I want. This issue gets more and more ridiculous as the amount of pieces increases. The koi pond stays the same size and more and more pieces go in it as you get to later puzzles. pieces will begin to overlap four or more deep in later puzzles. And the gremlin will just laugh at you. Then there's the normal small dev team stuff you could normally overlook;-Puzzle pieces in the koi pond are much smaller than on the board creating visual discrepancies.-When you "drop" a piece back to the pond it doesn't go where you drop it, it goes to a specific starting point in the middle of the action. So you cannot attempt any organization of pieces. -Sound settings made in main menu don't save to in-game. I wanted music off and SFX on. But then in-game its just everything off or everything on. -Messed with windows 10 title bars when played fullscreen and minimized to desktop.-Always launches in fullscreen even if you switched to windowed last play.-No saving mid-puzzle. -Etc.Just can't recommend it. At any price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												In Pixel Puzzles: Japan you need to solve a selection of 19 puzzles with different scenarios, difficulties and pictures. The concept is quite easy, you have pieces and you need to put them all together. The difference is, these pieces (who are also not your typical ones, with different shapes and sizes) are not static and they are always moving up and down and from left to right in some sort of koi pond. There is no timer for you to solve these puzzles and there are no tricks so take your time and have a bit of relaxing time if you have been playing something story heavy or you just want to escape from the usual violence on shooting in other games. The pictures are inspired by the Japanese culture so expect a lot of pink from the cherry bosom trees or some old statues and buildings. It took me around 12 hours to finish all these puzzles and it was a great choice to play between other games. As the levels progress so do you. You are a young disciple Monk, and as you advance in harder puzzles you will improve as well until you attain your “enlightenment”.  While the moving pieces was an interesting idea it may become a bit frustrating on the final puzzles. Some pieces become smaller and the number of them will increase so it means more pieces will be moving. If you want to click and drag a specific piece you saw this may prove to be harder considering there are so many moving and the mouse pointer did not feel so accurate at times. Just like when doing a normal puzzle, I always start with the surrounding frame and then move to one of the corners and keep going from there. Some puzzles can take more time than others and I struggled with one that had too many similar colors in all places which brings another flaw: there is no save or pause option. If you want to start a new level you may as well finish it, otherwise you will need to restart all over This is not an issue on most of the puzzles but if a puzzle is taking you longer than expected or you need to leave your PC, having an option to not start all over again would be a good thing to have.In the end this was a nice little time sink. The music is simple but relaxing enough but after a couple of hours I decided to put my own playlist of Zen/Meditation music and the results were much better. I felt relaxed and the game does exactly what you should expect.

												Imagine trying to put together a puzzle, but the spare pieces (or as the game calls them, "peices") are on an air hockey table. Every time you put a piece down, it gets mixed back into the jumbled mess. Throw in a few Chinese things in there because why the hell not, you're already mashing together enough East Asian things, a little racism only adds more flavor.If you're selling a generic jigsaw puzzle game, theme and gimmicks are super important to sell your product. But it feels like a white game design student who has only read about Japan in travel guides designed this thing. It's cringe-worthy.TL;DR - Bad gimmicky jigsaw puzzle game, cultural appropriation flavored. Not worth it for gameplay nor card drops.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Sad, but true: Put "Japan" in your game title and the game will sell.But I could let that "slide", because it's a puzzle game after all...PUZZLE - yes! Puzzle. Though the creator went out of his way to do everything to take the PUZZLE element out of the game.What's left? Well... do you know the experience of cutting & pasting multiple lines in a textfile? That's what this game is.Let me eleborate:1) You do not "rotate" the pieces, they are pre-fixed to be alligned correctly the moment you "fish" them out of the pond. 2) Double clicking somewhere around the area automatically fixes the position of your puzzle piece and thus takes away the challenging element. They stay fixed in that position also, so you already know you got the puzzle piece at the right spot.3) The shapes of the pieces are so easily distinguishable that you don't even have to look at the overall picture to arrange them together.What's fun about puzzle games? Not knowing which direction the puzzle piece goes, not knowing where to put it and having the joy of finally fitting one with the other after a long time of "puzzling".  The creator took all those 3 elements away and what's left is a drag... litterally dragging the pieces to the board and be done with it.Verdict: FAIL2/10

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												There are times in everyone's life when you're so stressed you have barely enough energy to play more than an old fashioned puzzle. When that times comes for you, stear clear from this one. The music isn't bad. The weirdly cut puzzle pieces aren't bad. The pictures aren't bad. The idea of the moving/floating puzzle pieces, while strange at first, isn't bad, theoretically. It doesn't allow easy organization of the pieces, and basically asks you to go about it one piece at the time. That could potentially have made the puzzles harder, but in an interesting way.Here's the problem: If you are basing the whole concept of your take on a traditional game on a mechanic that doesn't work, you are doing it wrong. And the "floating pieces" idea doesn't work, because the click detection on these floating pieces simply doesn't work. The game consitently fails to recognise the piece you click on, even when it is clearly on top of every other piece and you clearly click in the middle of the piece. The detection rate is so horrible, that it makes the game frustrating. It's plain and simple flawed execution of the main game mechanic.That aside, there is a rather limited number of puzzles (16 or so?), probably finishable in under 8 hours (many of my hours up there are just idling). The lack of any type of save function is another fatal flaw.So, no, this isn't a good puzzle game in any way. Get it really, really, really cheap with really low expectations.

Posted: January 26, 2015
												One of the few acutal "puzzle" games on steam (puzzle as in jigsaw puzzle, rather than the catch-all genre name); sadly, it isn't really all that impressive.  The early puzzles are easy enough but as more pieces get added to the more difficult puzzles, the "pool" that jumbles all the pieces gets so full that it is actually quite difficult picking up pieces.  In the end, the concept seems simple enough, but sadly the execution leaves a lot to be desired.  Only pick it up if you're getting it in one of the various game bundles out there.

Posted: June 6, 2014
												Looking for a good jigsaw game? So am I.This really is not it. It has some nice jigsaw variations, different edges on the pieces. Some beautiful photos for the faces aswell. All that is not the problem, the rest is.The game feels very uninspired, I really don't like the art style, and the music/sounds are not agreeing with me either.It's a small niche genre, not alot of games to choose from. Posted: July 25, 2015
												Maybe at first sight this game looks a bit boring or simple, but trust me, if you start playing it, you'll just want to play it more!After a long day, this can really help you to relieve stress and anger.The music from the game is really calm and it's refreshing for the soul.There were some annoying things, which aren't that bad, but I'll list them here:When you select a puzzle piece, it randomly picks another one, even if there is a larger space between the pieces.The game doesn't remember settings like Full screen/Windowes mode after you exit the game.And advertising on the main menu for other puzzle game from the developer(s).Maybe that last one, isn't so noticable and not everyone has an issue with it, but I didn't really liked it.So my final score for the game is a:9.5/10-Great game and if you have some change in your wallet, grab this little game and have fun with it!

Posted: September 10, 2014
												I purchased this game on sale and I only recommend this game when it's on sale.In all honesty, I've never been so irritated playing a game since the last time I've played League of Legends. Let me describe to you what is so irritating. The play area is made up of a table which you assemble the puzzle pieces on and there's a river/pool along the left and top edge of the screen that the unused pieces float around in. Now in the early levels where there's less pieces and the pieces are larger this pool is fine and works great. However, when you progress and the pieces become smaller and more of them it's almost impossible to click on the piece you need. The majority of the time spent on this game has been trying to click on a piece I need and picking up pieces that my cursor isn't even touching. I wish this game wasn't digital so I could flip the table over.Now if you can get passed the irritating pool the game is fine and enjoyable. It's a jigsaw puzzle game. You piece the puzzle together and you complete the puzzle. It's as simple as that and done well in that regard.

Posted: September 7, 2014
												(Review from September 2014)I bought this game when it was on sale for around 2 bucks and overall I think it's worth that.There are some negative aspects: Inaccuracy. If you try to pick up a piece you almost never get the one you wanted, especially on the last stages when there are many pieces floating in the pond. No save feature. If you leave your current puzzle, you'll have to start from scratch the next time. I often found myself in a puzzle without really knowing how the result is supposed to look like. The only preview you get is in the selection screen and very small. In order to see the full-sized picture, you first have to place enough pieces correctly and fill up the bar on the right, then you get a glimpse at the picture for a few seconds. Personally, I don't mind not having it in front of me the whole time, but it should be shown in the beginning.Apart from these points I enjoyed Pixel Puzzles: Japan as a nice and relaxing experience between fast-paced games.If you like jigsaw puzzles or want to earn some easy achievements (takes around 12-16 hours), this game is for you.

Posted: March 26, 2015
												Music is a nice calm pase is great for completing the puzzles, if you are into puzzles this one is for you.-Several puzzles-Several puzzles Styles.-Achievements.-Puzzles Unlocks.For me this was rather a great game game to relax and forget how many times i died in hotline miami 2 ;)

Posted: April 17, 2015
												Since there's really not that much to say about jigsaw puzzle games in general, this review will be a summary of pros and cons, accompanied with brief commentary by me.Pros-piece edges diversity: all puzzles have pieces with their own distinct edges (the interlocking bulges / notches), which rather give an original feeling to each puzzle.-audio: soothing Japanese background tune and sound effects-achievements: easy to accomplish a perfect game (100% achievements), only time and patience required, little skill.Cons-no save game option: can be a nuisance especially on the larger of the puzzles; several times i had to leave the game running until I got time again to complete a puzzle.-no player accounts: 1 player only, bit of a pity, since I’m father in a family of 4 gaming people, who want to track their progress separately.-amount of puzzles / smaller puzzles: there are 21 puzzles (6x60pcs / 5x112pcs / 4x153pcs / 3x220pcs / 1x350pcs / 2 additional puzzles of 153pcs (i think)); which is too few-hard to grab desired pieces from the pond: it's hard to precisely grab the piece you want from the pond, hard in such a way I’m wondering the developers have done this deliberately.-audio: only 1 background tuneIn short: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a soothing, little jigsaw puzzle game with little functionality. Would be better with more and larger puzzles, combined with a save game option. Picked it up at a sale (<€1), completed approximately 2 puzzles / week. Took my time enjoying puzzling. Perfected the game (100% achievements) in 17 hours and moved on. Probably never replaying Pixel Puzzles: Japan again, since there are other Pixel Puzzles versions on the market I want to complete. When my desire to puzzle comes back, that is.Greetings and have fun

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Nice game to spend a few hours on. Puzzles get more difficult the smaller the tiles are.Relaxing music.If only the tiles wouldn't make piles in the corners, that would be great.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a casual jigsaw game. It is the first jigsaw puzzle game on Steam and it is relaxing and fun.The gameplay is simple and self explenatory, just like in the original board game you have to fit together puzzle pieces to form a beautiful japanese scenery. There are 19 different puzzles, ranging from ones with 60 pieces to one with 350 pieces. Each puzzle in this game has a different picture but also the puzzle pieces differ as well. This game offers an unique experience since some of the puzzles have pieces with shapes that you won't see in real life. Unlike in real life you can see the image of the puzzle you are working on just before starting the level. There is a power-up that fills up and shows the original picture for a few seconds if used. There is no time or objectives, so the game is very relaxing and you have nothing to worry about. Also, there is a fish swimming in the river that you can play with, for fun. On the other hand, there are some disadvantages of this game. There is no save feature mid puzzle so if you leave a puzzle you have to start it over. That is a big problem in the last levels since they take a lot of time to finish so your only option is to leave your PC open. Another flaw is selecting the pieces you want. The puzzle pieces float around a river around the ''table''. That is a good ideea, but when you try to click on the piece you want you will probably end up selecting another piece and having to put it back into the river and sometimes the piece you want disappears into another point of the river.The graphics are pretty nice and the japanese pictures very beautiful. The music is relaxing just as the gameplay.I recommend this game, casual, relaxing and fun, 8/10.

												A nice, relaxing game to play when you're bored.The Puzzles become gradually more challenging and there are almost 20 of them.For people who like puzzling I can recommend that game.Unfortunately the mouse-click-handling often behaves very unexpected, so that instead of picking the exact puzzle piece you're clicking on it picks another one which actually was drawn below the one you clicked on.But puzzles are games which require a lot of patience anyway, so I guess that shouldn't be too bad.Oh and yeah, as I've read in other reviews, there's actually no save-feature... so you need to finish a puzzle in one session.(Also it doesn't even remember the settings you chose in the options menu, e.g. volume, fullscreen, etc.)

I'm not sure if it is worth the money, but I enjoyed it playing from time to time.Also, it is a great pick-up for 100% achievement hunters.

Posted: September 12, 2014
												I enjoy doing puzzles and this game hits that itch.  Fix puzzle piece selection detection and you've got my vote. (9-12)Pros  Relaxing atmosphere of music and theme.   Nice puzzle picturesCons  Terrible puzzle piece selector detection!  On the later levels there are constant overlapping pieces floating around to grab. Even if you are clicking on a piece that is on top it will randomly grab a piece.  It can take minutes to get a particular piece you want..  If this alone was fixed, I'd recommend this puzzle game more.     Some of the sounds/music can get old after a while. I wish there was more music selection.    A few puzzles had so little color variation, it was a matter of guessing all combinations ( cherry blossom pic in particular ).      Most others were fine. Wantsa section on side where you can put pieces you want to keep tabs on but not clutter up the puzzle picture space.  it allows you to hang pieces on the border, but thats not much. be able to combine pieces that you know fit together, without knowing their proper location yet.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												I'd recommend this game for folks who love puzzles but are short on space, have cats, or for some other reason are unable to pull out a 1000+ piece puzzle to assemble. To fully enjoy the game, players should probably also like games that require catching something that is moving with a click of the controller...or fishing games. There are, however, a few points that could be polished up:- The mouse pointer is not very accurate and sometimes sluggish.- The game lacks a true working space to organize selected puzzle pieces. (If you accidentally put the right piece in the right place on the board the piece will lock down, so it's a bit risky - and un-fun - to only have the puzzle board to place various fished-out pieces.)- You can catch the koi...but it does nothing.- There's no save option. Be prepared to have enough time to complete the puzzle when you sit down to play (most don't take *that* long) or to leave the game running in the background when something comes up.- The speed of the flow in the puzzle piece "pond" is not adjustable. When combined with mouse accuracy issues, clicking for puzzle pieces can be fairly random.- The pieces get smaller as the number of pieces increases...which, at times, made me feel like I might go blind. (Playing on laptop.)The above list seems like a lot of things that can be improved, I know. And if any of the above would drive you bonkers, then maybe this game won't be a good choice for you. However, if the above points won't ruin your gaming experience and you love puzzles/puzzling games, then I reccomend playing Pixel Puzzles: Japan.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												A very nice game with magnificent images from Japan. Nice ambient music and sounds, and of course newly added achievements for the hunters out there. It is a little bit of addictive, so do not forget to take your eyes away from the screen once in a while. Also prepare for a lot of rage explosions while trying to pick the piece you want but you pick all the other ones … but the one you actually want. Great puzzle (literally) game over all. Posted: September 12, 2014
												If you like building puzzles, Pixel Puzzles: Japan should be right up your alley.  But it doesn't come without it's share of problems that distract from the overall enjoyment of the game.First to deserve mention is the inability to save your progress (at least, I could not find any such feature or mechanic anywhere).  If you start building a puzzle, you need to commit to finishing it.  For the earlier puzzles that have fewer pieces this is not a problem.  But getting along to the more advanced puzzles with a lot more pieces, it takes one quite a while to complete a puzzle, which you now have to do in one sitting.Which leads me to the second distraction.  When building a puzzle, all of the available pieces are floating along the left and top sides of the screen.  You pick a piece up from these areas and drag them onto the puzzle for placement.For early puzzles this is easy.  However, once the puzzles get to have 100+ pieces, the areas get a bit crowded and picking up a piece becomes a mini-game in itself.  A frustrating one at that.You can clearly see a piece floating about that you wish to pick up, but click on it and somehow you will have picked up a piece underneath it or floating off to the side of it.  Sometimes it takes up to 10 tries just to pick up the piece you want.And dropping an unwanted piece results in all of the pieces around the drop point to disappear and reappear somewhere else.  Thus, you sometimes inadvertently lose the piece you actually want, because you dropped an unwanted pick-up on top of it.Lastly, there are only 21 puzzles to build.  Once you've built them all, the game is pretty much over unless you wish to re-build a certain puzzle.These are some minor niggles and personal experiences that shouldn't detract from the overall game, but I feel are worth mentioning.If you like building puzzles, you should give Pixel Puzzles: Japan a go.  If you like building puzzles but get frustrated easily, I'd lay caution in the road as you might fall to pieces while trying to pick up the pieces....

Posted: September 17, 2014
												Very fun, relaxing, and a nice timewaster. The finished puzzle images look gorgeous and the harder ones are quite satisfying to accomplish. The one song that plays during the game is fairly decent, but some people may find it annoying after awhile. Luckily, there is an option to turn off the sound. The price isn't too bad, although I did purchase it when it was on sale, and as of now there are 21 different puzzles to play. The developers did mention "multiple free bonus puzzles" so there might be more to come in the future.My only two complaints are that having the puzzle pieces constantly moving around makes it frustratingly difficult to grab the one that you want, so you may have to take out a few pieces before getting a certain one. My other complaint is that there seems to be no way of saving my progress on a puzzle so I can come back to it later. It's not really a big deal with the smaller, easier puzzles, but once you get up to 220 pieces and beyond, it can be a pain to have to assemble the entire puzzle in one go.Despite those issues I mentioned, this is a lovely puzzle game. I highly recommend it to any jigsaw puzzle fans looking for something to unwind and relax with.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												Here’s something I never thought I’d say: I actually rather enjoyed Pixel Puzzles: Japan.Aside from the rapid onset of carpal tunnel, this game wasn’t terrible. I’m not sure if it was situational when I played it (at nights while staying oceanfront) or if the game is actually acceptable but I had fun. In fact, considering I paid nothing for it, the only real flaw I saw was that god forsaken river the pieces floated in. Oh my god I have never been so annoyed by anything in a game before. And don’t even get me started on the “zen” water pipe thing. Word of advice: Immediately stuff that stupid koi in there and shut it up. Also why on earth are we not allowed to save progress on a puzzle and come back to it later?I guess the game is kinda crap.. but I didn’t spend a penny on it and I had fun, so yeah take from that what you will.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a cute puzzle game with some beautiful pictures to put together. Although the selection of puzzles is a bit small, I did spend quite a bit of time completing them all. The added difficulty of fishing the pieces out of the koi pond was a fun challenge, though it was difficult to see the pieces without yanking them all out of the pond once I reached the harder puzzles. I could have also done without the oddly shaped pieces in some situations as well (particularly the swirl-shaped edges of one puzzle). Overall a solid 4/5 game for me.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												Its a good puzzle game once u notice how to do it.TIP: When u build the puzzle start with the boundaries left, righht top down & then the rest.Its not too hard a bit tricky but fun sort of OK. I reccomend this if u like puzzle games.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												Bad  points : The game has only 21 jigsaw puzzles so far by now (19 achievements and 2 in addition), which can be completed in 5 hours more or less. There is no save option so you will always have to leave the computer on while you want to take a pause from completing a puzzle. There is no zooming option which makes 200 plus pieces puzzles difficult. Another problem comes from the fish pond where you'll have quite a hard time trying to catch the piece that you want. There is no option to puzzelize your own images from the computer nor a way to add other jigsaw puzzles other than waiting for an update.Good points : The game is light and fast even on pretty old machines, thou sometimes it crashes without other programs open. The fish and the fountain can be both forgotten when you'll put one into the other XD so you'll not catch it anymore while searching your piece thou it's kinda sad seeing it there...poor fish. There are nice song pieces that change often, so if you'll not like a specific song, you'll have to wait just a while and it's gone. Since they are pieces, it also contributes to the light weight of the game. You can mute the songs if you really dislike them. In the extras there are the photos of the puzzles, so be sure to check it before attempting to complete a puzzle. The images are kinda tricky with many similar colors this makes the puzzles fun, not to mention that they are wonderful. If you'll find the images too difficult for you, the anchor system of the pieces will come handy for you, thou it is a bit too sensible. The pond idea with the pieces floating in it is also nice but if you can get rid of the fish, you cannot do the same with the flowers and pieces can hide under them, like when they stuck in a corner... kinda tricky. Overall it's really nice, also because you can repeat the puzzles that you want, or force yourself by deleting the data and starting all over.

Posted: April 11, 2015
												It's what you'd expect, some small jigsaw puzzles (60 pieces thru 330 pieces) attached to some achievements to incentivize playing. I could do without the floating puzzle pieces, and the use of space could be more efficient as there's limited space to drag and place the pieces forcing you to let them float.  Get it in a bundle and you're good to go.   The achievements are all easily unlocked.

Posted: February 12, 2016
												The first game in the Pixel Puzzles series that I played. It delivers the jigsaw puzzle experience that you'd expect (imagine).  It's okay, there's not much to say about it. Rotating pieces is not possible, they are always in the correct orientation - I have no issue with this. There is some sort of hint system, but I haven't used it very much at all. Instead, there is a delightful exploit that efficiently helps with the more aggravating, end-game pictures. One minor annoyance is that you cannot enjoy a moment with the picture you just completed, as there is immediately a popup on top of it.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												This game is as simple as it sounds. You put together digital jigsaw puzzles in the theme of Japanese locations and nature settings. The difficulty steadily increases with increasingly complex images and higher piece-counts until you reach the end. The later puzzles initially seemed as if they could take forever but I could tell that there was some type of subtle assist in place, as I too often would find the piece I needed when the situation should have been like a needle-in-a-haystack. Probably because of limited screen real estate making it too complex to play completely true-to-life. No matter, the game is enjoyable and plenty relaxing. The sounds are naturally fairly soothing but i also enjoyed listening to some albums while I played and collected the achievements.

Posted: May 23, 2015
												Who knew solving jigsaw puzzles could lead to total enlightenment, well, at least it does for the monk in the game ~There are 19 puzzles to solve, and all of them are Japanese landscapes, which are very beautiful.The difficulty rises as you unlock more puzzles. Basically, after you've played a few of them, the number of pieces will increase.The music is relaxing, though it loops a lot, and does not vary much, which I thought was a little disappointing.My biggest problem with the game is the mechanic to pick up a piece. Sometimes, my mouse will pick up the wrong piece and it will take several tries for it to finally detect the one I wanted.In addition, you can't save the game while doing the jigsaw puzzle, so you better not close it if you don't want to lose your progress. It is a relaxing and just a fine casual game to kill some time. But some parts of it are frustrating.Despite some nice features, I will not recommend the game, unless you get it at a decent price or from a bundle.My reason being that picking up pieces was very annoying >_< especially at the end of the game, when there was a lot of pieces in the water. It made the game less fun...it also strained my eyes =_=;~ Hope this review was helpful.

												You can pick up any piece, and I mean it, you can grab ANY piece, but the one you want.  It's so frustrating. If you could at least pick the piece you wanted, it'd be way easier. Oh, and after finishing that puzzle, which took me about 2 hours, the game still says that I have completed "0 puzzles"... I mean, really?! Ouch. I wouldn't recommend it... unless you enjoy raging at the computer. I just wanted to relax and now I want to throw the laptop through the window, great job Pixel Puzzles: Japan!

												Rating: 6/10Classic jigsaw puzzle game with various shapes and Japanese theme. Process is unlockable, you will go through 19 different puzzles, from 60 pieces to 350 pieces. Posted: March 20, 2015
												Bad  points : The game has only 21 jigsaw puzzles so far by now (19 achievements and 2 in addition), which can be completed in 5 hours more or less. There is no save option so you will always have to leave the computer on while you want to take a pause from completing a puzzle. There is no zooming option which makes 200 plus pieces puzzles difficult. Another problem comes from the fish pond where you'll have quite a hard time trying to catch the piece that you want. There is no option to puzzelize your own images from the computer nor a way to add other jigsaw puzzles other than waiting for an update.Good points : The game is light and fast even on pretty old machines, thou sometimes it crashes without other programs open. The fish and the fountain can be both forgotten when you'll put one into the other XD so you'll not catch it anymore while searching your piece thou it's kinda sad seeing it there...poor fish. There are nice song pieces that change often, so if you'll not like a specific song, you'll have to wait just a while and it's gone. Since they are pieces, it also contributes to the light weight of the game. You can mute the songs if you really dislike them. In the extras there are the photos of the puzzles, so be sure to check it before attempting to complete a puzzle. The images are kinda tricky with many similar colors this makes the puzzles fun, not to mention that they are wonderful. If you'll find the images too difficult for you, the anchor system of the pieces will come handy for you, thou it is a bit too sensible. The pond idea with the pieces floating in it is also nice but if you can get rid of the fish, you cannot do the same with the flowers and pieces can hide under them, like when they stuck in a corner... kinda tricky. Overall it's really nice, also because you can repeat the puzzles that you want, or force yourself by deleting the data and starting all over.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												Since there's really not that much to say about jigsaw puzzle games in general, this review will be a summary of pros and cons, accompanied with brief commentary by me.Pros-piece edges diversity: all puzzles have pieces with their own distinct edges (the interlocking bulges / notches), which rather give an original feeling to each puzzle.-audio: soothing Japanese background tune and sound effects-achievements: easy to accomplish a perfect game (100% achievements), only time and patience required, little skill.Cons-no save game option: can be a nuisance especially on the larger of the puzzles; several times i had to leave the game running until I got time again to complete a puzzle.-no player accounts: 1 player only, bit of a pity, since I’m father in a family of 4 gaming people, who want to track their progress separately.-amount of puzzles / smaller puzzles: there are 21 puzzles (6x60pcs / 5x112pcs / 4x153pcs / 3x220pcs / 1x350pcs / 2 additional puzzles of 153pcs (i think)); which is too few-hard to grab desired pieces from the pond: it's hard to precisely grab the piece you want from the pond, hard in such a way I’m wondering the developers have done this deliberately.-audio: only 1 background tuneIn short: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a soothing, little jigsaw puzzle game with little functionality. Would be better with more and larger puzzles, combined with a save game option. Picked it up at a sale (<€1), completed approximately 2 puzzles / week. Took my time enjoying puzzling. Perfected the game (100% achievements) in 17 hours and moved on. Probably never replaying Pixel Puzzles: Japan again, since there are other Pixel Puzzles versions on the market I want to complete. When my desire to puzzle comes back, that is.Greetings and have fun

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
For the memory of the Jigsaw-Mania in the 70sI remember the time quite well, when my cousins an me got a box of Jigsaws each birthday and x-mas... It was during the early 70s, and Jigsaws were all the rage...I think just because of this I am still so deeply fascinated by puzzle games of any color... Of course, this is a computer rendition of that time and as the original it is all about zen... Jigsaws are superficially very simple games of search and stack, the end product is on the cover of the box. This game captures a lot of this style, and it's all about Japan in this game. With a lot of beautiful sceneries and a fitting sound. Even a priceless Koi is swimming in the pond in which all the puzzle parts are floating.Can you wish for more, dear puzzler?Indeed you could, but that would probably take away the charm of the game at all. It's simple, it's as fast as you wish it to be and it is quite fun when you remember that this kind of game are casual games. Not to be played in one session, but when you need that kind of relaxation.I would recomend this game for the sceneries, the calmness and medative quality it has and because it is an emulation of the original Jigsaws, that still can keep people peeled to the solution, even if it takes weeks to solve.Have fun playing the game.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												How is it that I can click directly on a puzzle piece and if there's another one within a mile of it, the other one will be selected?  This game has the worst z-ordering ever.  Compounded by the blasted pieces moving around in the frustrating pond.The floating koi pond gimmick would be nice, except all the pieces cluster in the bottom left.  So it's nearly impossible to find a piece unless it's got a very distinctive color.  There is no other way to look at the pieces, of course, so you either end up hoarding them in the puzzle area, or tossing them back so they can hide every other piece you're interested in.  Normally, finding edge pieces is relatively easy, but because I couldn't sort through them individually and they conspired to get in the way of my clicks, I ended up hunting for edge pieces for nearly half an hour.  Normally that's the easy part.Finally, even if you know pieces go together and try to connect them, they won't connect to each other.  They will only snap in at their very specific places on the board.  Which is a huge step down from real puzzles, and some other puzzle games I've played.  Of course they wouldn't have a feature to name and group puzzle pieces together and get them out of the way.  It's the pond or nothing.44 minutes and I'm done.  I'm just leaving it on to farm cards at the moment.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												I'm a big fan of jigsaw puzzles, and I was excited when I recieved this as a gift. Now... I really hate to write negative reviews, as I try to look at the effort and love that were put in to games. But sometimes there are just games that I can't give a positive review to. And sadly? This is one of them. =Complete Review= (TL:DR version and Conclusion at the bottom)=The Gameplay: 2/5= It's rather mediocre, in terms of gameplay. Puzzle pieces snap in place when placed on their correct spot on the grid, which would be better if the pieces snapped to eachother instead... But I can understand developer-wise why they wouldn't do that, due to the fact it would be a bit of a hassle if a player put a combined-piece back in to the pond. And, it's still better than the pieces not snapping in to place at all. Speaking of the pond, it's probably a big player in the game's issues. It would be fine if it only moved the pieces around, that's a bit annoying, but I get what they were trying to do. But because of the pieces moving around, it makes picking up pieces just flat out annoying because of it sometimes glitching up pieces. You'll try to pick up a edge piece, and wind up picking up a piece that's practically another whole piece away.  Half the time I just move all the pieces from the pond on to the board, just so that way I can pick them up right.The powerup in the game is also... Strange. I only used it once so I could see how it worked. It changes the background to show the rest of the image so you'll know where to put the pieces, but personally I found it more fun to just put the puzzle together without it.  And the koi, don't get me started on the koi. Just don't... About the best part involving the koi is sticking it in the sozu. I'd say that's a redeeming feature, as the bloody fish got in my way a number of times when picking up puzzle pieces. But some people would likely just find that cruel, so it's a your-mileage-may-vary thing.=The Graphics: 3/5= Now this, is a redeeming feature of the game. The graphics look  nice in my opinion! The UI is done well, the actual images for the puzzles are of good quality, the pieces having different unique designs to mix things up in the more difficult levels. It's quite asthetically pleasing! But it's not to the level that would be considered eyecatching, and breathtaking. Well done, but not embellished much. Which, well, that's good or bad, depending on your preferences. For the concept, a simpler style does work well. But for those wanting a more ornate, and intricate looking style, this would likely not be all that pleasing to the eye for them.=The Audio: 1/5=  Ugh.. Now this is the part I absolutely hated. It was fine for maybe the first two puzzles. But the music with the haphazard sound effects tossed in just doesn't work... I mean, sure, the sound effects fit the theme, sort of. But the mixed volumes of the sound effects and the music would be more prone to cause tension as opposed to relaxation. Which, is what the theme aims for: a zen-style. I personally muted it and played more relaxing tunes to it. I'd suggest that you pick your favorite zen or relaxing music and turn that on instead if you play this.=TL;DR/Pros & Cons=ProsA pretty pleasing jigsaw puzzle game. Has achievements that are fairly easy to get.The pictures are lovely.NeutralYou get to put the koi in the sozu. The graphics are pretty simple.Puzzle pieces snap to the frame rather than to eachother.ConsThe game is a bit glitchy because of the bloody pond.The music and sfx are terrible IMO.Your progress on the puzzles are not saved.=The Conclusion: 4/10= It's a decent game if it's on a sale above 75%, but if not, it's definitely not worth the full price. It was a cute idea, but the execution was not done very well. I've played much better jigsaw puzzle games for free, of which I'd link, but that would be in poor taste. A quick google search of "Flash Jigsaw Puzzle" should come up with some. I appreciate your time, and thank you for reading my review.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a jigsaw puzzle simulation game. It is said to have some light gameplay elemtns mixed in with putting together jigsaw puzzles. Putting together puzzles without all the mess of getting the pieces out, making sure you get them facing up, clearing the space to put it together, and then putting it away later is nice. The actual act of putting the pieces into the puzzle is fun. Some other virtual puzzles I've done are far too forgiving on how close you need to put the pieces, but this game does a good job of making you put it in the right place before it'll stick without it being too horribly specific to make you second guess yourself constantly. Some of these puzzles were fun to put together with neat pictures as a result. Also, there were some interesting edges and piece shapes which gave the different puzzles a little life and challenge to put together. The jigsaw puzzle part is good. My issues come in when you're looking at the gameplay elements that have been included to spice the game up. Either these elements should be eliminated, or there needs to be more of the elements. The elements that are there are mostly annoying or useless. Being able to pick up a fish and move it around isn't really challenging or fun, it's just useless. Completing puzzles to unlock more is also a bit useless, as anyone doing this for the sake of doing the puzzles is going to do them all anyway so having them all available to pick from would be nice. Plus, leveling up for completing puzzles just to unlock other puzzles is also fairly useless in the grand scheme of things if the only reason for them is to play more of the game you were most likely going to play more of anyway. The annoying part is how the puzzle pieces are stuck in a pool of water around the corner the table. So the pieces will freely float around, covering each other up and bouncing around, which makes them difficult to sift through. There's also an annoying priority going on. See, they have somewhat of an order. Pieces go from top left to top right, then down a row starting on the left again, and so on. So if you click in an area that would select multiple pieces, whichever one is highest on that priority list will be picked up, even if you clicked mostly on a different piece or didn't want that one. Also, if you drop a piece back in the water it, along with any other pieces it lands on, will sink and respawn in a spot in the water on the left. So the constant movement, piece priority, and sinking situation all make for a very frustrating puzzle experience. There's not really any penalty for these things. It just takes longer and is more frustrating. It wastes your own time and tries your patience, whch I don't think is a good reason to have the elements. The only useful element is that, once you get enough pieces in, you can click on the sun and reveal the entire picture for a few seconds to refresh your memory... even though most people would be able to look at it the while time when doing a real puzzle.On the other hand, there could be MORE elements and it'd make the game more fun, or at least have it make more sense. For instance, maybe something with time. A time limit, or just a timer to record your time. Some type of score for using the piece you grab and taking points away for throwing a piece back. Reasons to go faster and be more precise, plus giving a point to the tedious design. Getting better ranks to unlock perks or just to unlock puzzles. Having online leaderboards to compete for scores or times with others. There are plenty of things that could be added to make the current model of the game make more sense and possibly make it more enjoyable as a video game. Even just a save feature would be nice. In real life, many people will take breaks from big puzzles. Without a save feature, you can't do that here unless you want to leave your game running the entire time, which not everyone wants to do. A few of the puzzles were made up of similar looking things to the point of resorting to random placement to find where anything went. Maybe my eyes just suck, but they were not fun as trial and error challenges. Like the one with all the flowers... my word. Also, most of the puzzles look rather similar to each other anyway, which makes some sense with the common theme of Japan, but I still think more variety could've been had. I only found a few of the pictures interesting to look at and try to solve. What I'm saying is that Pixel Puzzles: Japan falls just a bit short of being a good puzzle simulation, and falls very short of being a fun interactive gaming experience. There needs to be more or less features to make this work well either way, at least for my taste. I played all the way through it, aside from the bonus puzzles. I got all the achievements and did all the main puzzles. I was very worn out near the middle but kept on going to see if it got any different. It really didn't. This game was ten hours of the same thing that, despite doing more puzzles and being a decent amount of puzzles for the price, wasn't a fun experience towards the last half. Changing the elements would make it better and possibly could've made me enjoy this game as a whole. However, I just can't say I enjoyed it. The first few puzzles were fun, but it gets old fast. I got this for free and... as mean as it sounds, I still feel like it was a waste. At least the last half was a waste of my time as I didn't enjoy it, but I wanted to review it and give it a fair chance for reviewing purposes. I feel I've done that, and I honestly cannot recommend it as is, especially at the 7 dollar asking price. Pixel Puzzles: Japan gets a 3/10 for having potential to be a good puzzle simulation or puzzle video game, but failing to do much justice to either camp.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Lots of production value, but bad for jigsaw solving.I've played  bunch of puzzle games (the good ones let you download nice pictures from flickr and do these, so they're basically endless), but none have gone out of their way so much to make this a different experience. Pro: lots of Japanese knick-knacks and animations, very nice feelCon: not suited to jigsaw solving.No save feature (I have that at home doing it on a table, why can't the game save?), pieces that go together don't snap together and have to be moved seperately, and because of this, you basically need to start with the corners and edges because then they'll snap to their final positions. However, good luck finding these in the "pond" where the pieces float around instead of waiting to be sorted - and if you have found them that doesn't mean the game will give them to you when you click them.You might decide to bear this for the 21 puzzles that are included, or you might decide to get something better instead. I'll do the latter.[Update: I'm playing this after all for the achievements, and the most aggravating thing by far is that it won't give you the piece you click on half of the time. I still wouldn't recommend playing this.]

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Do not recommend. This is not a game for anyone who actually likes puzzles.The pieces that are not being used float around the border in a pond. Endlessly trying to fish out pieces and consistently getting the wrong ones is frustrating. (Or that stupid fish if you're really unlucky) I'm not sure if the person who made this game has put a puzzle together, but that's not really how puzzles work. It would be nice if there was a way to turn off the animation so I can end this simple frustration.In additions, pieces will not stick together on the board. They only stick to the proper place. Meaning, if you found four pieces that go together, tough cookies! You have to wait to find every border piece so you can find the "spot" for this thing and put them all in place before they will actually stick together. Again, that's not how puzzles work!While I appreciate having goals, having to do the easy puzzles to get to the hard ones would be just fine if I didn't get motion sickness thanks to the damned pond of pieces. The music got annoying after two puzzles, It's just a few plucks on a koto in an endless loop. Not sure if you unlock different music later, but after a bit this was more grating than relaxing. I gave up.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												It's quite amazing that a game about putting together jigsaw puzzles with a zen theme manages to be such a stressful experience.It makes me wonder if the developers ever played with an actual puzzle, as most of the staples of it (ie, looking for patterns among the pieces, setting apart groups of them that seem like they go together, seeing where they fit with the whole picture, leaving the puzzle and going back to it later, etc) are just not possible in this game. Forget about going for specific pieces; you can click all you want on the piece that caught your eye, the game will still give you the piece it thinks you deserve instead. Since they're constantly moving, you'll helplessly watch them drift away from you over and over. The pieces do not `click`, with each other, they just snap to their place on the main grid. So much space on the screen is wasted with useless graphics and blank space that could have been used for much needed game space. The lack of a quick save is a big flaw as well.The pictures are alright, if a bit uninspired and the shapes of the pieces are all nice and varied. The sounds are fine, but they do get grating after a while, especially since it's always the same, over and over.The game is still playable, and you'll barely notice its flaws in the smaller puzzles, but it's all uphill from there. I managed to finish it, but that's mainly because I'm an achievement junkie, more than anything else.
