number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
TL;DR: A fine jigsaw puzzle game that however gets irritating later on because of the lack of saving feature and unreliable jigsaw piece catching. Pixel Puzzles presents one of the simplest forms of puzzles, jigsaw puzzles, now ported from real life to computer screen. As you'd expect by the subtitle, the theme is Japan. This shows itself both in the puzzles themselves and the interface.In the interface there's a metagame of you being some kind of a Buddhist guru who levels up and becomes ever more enlightened as you solve more puzzles. The puzzles are at first quite easy (i.e. few pieces) but as you "get more enlightened" more difficult (i.e. larger) puzzles are unlocked.Puzzle pictures look good and usually contain various temples, parks, cherry trees and castles from the classic Land of the Rising Sun - you won't find anime girls, video game references or weird game shows here, IMO rather unfortunately actually as it would have introduced more variety. Instead, all is serene and beautiful and the music is somewhat relaxing mix in a traditional Japanese style. I frankly muted it after a while and listened to my own music because it was making me sleepy.Gameplay is the important part. The jigsaw pieces are floating in a pond next to the puzzle table and you have to pick them up with mouse cursor. It's sometimes difficult to pick the one you want as the pieces can float over each other and for some reason the one you are pointing with mouse might not be the one picked up - that's rather annoying especially in the larger puzzles where the pieces are smaller.Obviously some simplifications have been taken in the design. The pieces are of fixed orientation, so they never need to be rotated. They also lock in place if you drop them close enough to the intended spot. You also can't see the whole picture but before the puzzle and after gaining enough "insight" (i.e. completing large enough part of the puzzle) and then only for a short time. As a minor note, the pieces on the board obscure what's underneath, and once you are close to finishing they might be camouflaged in within the puzzle pattern and there's no way to highlight them for easy notice.In my opinion the major flaw of the game is the lack of saving feature: once you have started a puzzle, you need to complete it or start over again later. This is especially frustrating for the largest puzzles (300-350 pieces) of the end-game as they can take an hour or more to complete. Actually 8 hours of my game time was accumulated when I cracked and left the game running for the night to finish the halfway done last puzzle I started the previous night.Overall I didn't enjoy it very much, but that's not because of it being a bad game but because I grew frustrated when I couldn't progress with the larger puzzles and then couldn't save to continue later. The puzzles are actually quite nice, the jigsaws varied and the challenge is okay. Only in larger puzzles did I get a headache trying to find and the pick the pieces I wanted. In my opinion, there could have been more "revelations" of the puzzle picture to speed up the game, and I found the lack of saving horrendous. With that it's a mixed bag with slightly more goodies than ickies.In effect I spend about 15 hours with it completing every puzzle except the very large optional ones. For a patient, casual player it's a good game except for the lack of saving feature. It might even work as a team game, played together with a friend. For a less patient one, perhaps get it on sale or bundle like I did.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												The object is simple, grab jigsaw pieces floating in a pond along the top and side edge of the screen and assemble them into a picture in the middle. No timer. No real special abilities or upgrades. No contrived storyline. Just a neat little way to pass some time and look at some pretty pictures.Complexity is added along the way by increasing the piece count of new puzzles or by tackling a picture with fewer unique, easily identifiable features, but the most noticeable addition is the actual "cut" of the pieces with each new stage. Initially we're introduced to the more conventional shapes we'd expect to see jigsaw pieces to come in, but as you progress things are mixed up by having the interlocking segments of the pieces cut into shapes relevant to the picture for that puzzle. So, a watery picture might have pieces with interlocking segments in the shape of waves, for example, or another set might have tiny little temples or trees connecting each piece (though no Godzilla shapes are anywhere to be found, sadly). It's a really fresh take on an old formula that manages to hold your interest and keep you guessing for longer than it might have otherwise, but thankfully this really helps it to stand out.Another factor which makes it stand out is its presentation. Everything is presented with an air of tranquillity, from the constant gentle twangs of various Japanese string instruments, to the flow and splashing of water throughout that makes you want to go to the toilet at least once every puzzle set. Visually, there's no great flare or anything flashy going on, everything is clean and simple and in keeping with the overall style and tone of the game helping it make for a sedate and pleasant experience.During my time with the 21 puzzles (19 regular, unlockable sets, and 2 "bonus" sets that are unlocked from the beginning but don't seem to count towards overall progress, oddly), I only found myself having any difficulty with two of the sets, which was partly down to the finale's piece count, but also the lack of distinct features on their pictures, which is one of the few minor complaints I'd have with the game. I know that the colours and shapes in each picture scene has to be kept relatively similar throughout, otherwise you'd find every piece way too easily, but that doesn't mean the images have to be uninteresting. It would have been nice to assemble something that was a greater showcase of Japan and its culture, like pedestrians crossing the Shibuya intersection or some talking toilets or a schoolgirl underwear vending machine. But, instead, we have to be content with some temples or golf courses. Which are OK... I guess.Another minor gripe I had with it was the lack of a save feature. This isn't a problem for the easier early stages, but towards the end I could see it being a real issue for some as you might want to put an hour or so aside for a couple of the later, harder sets. Another, more pressing pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ though, was actually selecting the pieces from the pond. Again, this isn't so much a concern at the start, but by the end the pond is so full of moving pieces that grabbing one out of it becomes a real problem, to the extent that more often than not the piece I clicked on wouldn't be what came out and I'd appear to have some near by random piece instead, with me having to remove all the unwanted surrounding pieces before finally being able to get the one I wanted. A really strange oversight in an otherwise well made game.So, while it's not without its flaws, overall I really enjoyed my time with it. Full disclosure, I got the game free as part of a promotion on a bundle site, but even had I paid full price I'd still be happy with it. So if you've got a bit of spare time, a little patience, and some extra money to blow on a throwaway purchase, then I could easily point you towards this game to satisfy your crazy, insatiable jigsaw lust.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Little Disclaimer: I got this game in a bundle, so I didn't buy full price for it. I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy this game at full price.The reason is rather simple: This game fails on almost every level.It is supposed to be a jigsaw puzzle game, yet the engine is seriously flawed:  You cannot attach pieces to each other even if you know they fit. You can only fix them to their final position. This makes it "kind of" easy to solve every puzzle: Choose a position, drag every puzzle piece to that position until one fits. Rinse and repeat. When several pieces are on top of each other, it seem to be pure randomness which one is selected by clicking. It may be the bottom-most one. It never is "the one visible that I want to click". Sometimes you have to shovel several pieces away from one position to finally select the one you want. The "pond" is a nice idea, it's implementation however heavily collides with the idea of a relaxing jigsaw puzzle game. Instead of having a quiet atmosphear, there always is something moving. The form of the pond (at least on my resolution) results in pieces cluttering on one side of the screen. As all pieces swim, I sometimes had to "hunt" a piece along the screen: It always tried to "hide" beneath other ones yet the one selected on click was a different one. The kai was disturbing as well but at least that could be removed (see achievements). The other puzzle game from the developers hints that they have a very strange idea about what relaxing jigsaw puzzle games should look like... There is no area to sort pieces. When for real puzzles, you might want to sort "border pieces" or "blue pieces" to one stack, you can only heap them up on the playing area, here. You might consider using the pond but every piece thrown into the pond changes location. Not only does it flow away over time; it immediately is put to a random place when dropped. This also is very frustrating when "digging" for a single piece by throwing everything else back into the pond: You easily throw away the desired piece on accident and then it's hard to find again.  I've played freeware puzzle games that allowed to customize the puzzles (choose your own picture, choose number of pieces). This game does not support any of this. When even the addition of new puzzles is worth an update post, there's something seriously wrong with the engine.The puzzles themselves were not too bad although I sometimes thought they were missing contrast to tell the pieces apart from each other. Most later puzzles I solved with a lot of the "Rinse and Repeat"-tactic. The music bored me to hell but may seem relaxing to some. Still, the most positive thing I can say about this game is that it's rather easy to achieve 100% completion on it. You don't need any skill, just some time.

												It’s a total disaster. What do you need for assembling a jigsaw puzzle? 1, a big table to group puzzle by type/color2, a safe places to store you workIt’s just that simple. However, this game fail on both conditions.1, the puzzle pieces keep floating around. There’s no way to group the puzzle properly. I just finished the 350 pieces puzzle and it looked disgusting. To make thing even worst, the click detection was poorly designed.  It feels like you are playing FPS game after a drinking contest. Everythins is moving. You miss, you miss and you miss.2. No save in this game. What are they thinking? It was not fun doing a 300 pieces puzzle non-stop.For jigsaw puzzle lover, do not buy it. Save you time and money.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												This game would be pretty fun, but once you get to a certain puzzle size, you can't even pick up the pieces you want because of the stupid implementation.  The main problems are:1) When there are multiple puzzle pieces layered over each other, the one you pick up isn't the one that's on the top.  It should definitely be the one on the top, as the way it is now you don't ever know what piece you're getting.2) When you place a piece back into the pool of pieces, they all spawn in the same place on the left.  So all the pieces tend to congregate in one place after a while.  When you combine this with point #1, it makes it impossible to pick up the piece you want.  The returned pieces should spawn where you placed them in the pool, or even just in a random place.The bad UI isn't such a big deal in the earlier puzzles since there are less pieces, but the game is nearly unplayable after a certain point.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												As someone who loves doing physical jigsaw puzzles, I looked forward to digging into this game. While it is a gorgeous aesthetic, the shifting flow of pieces around the board was incredibly annoying to me. I organize my physical puzzles by color and the inability to have any organization or structure made the game much less enjoyable. Plus it was very difficult to selevt what piece you wanted. While the music was good, there is only one track while you're working on puzzles and one track while in the menu as I recall, and that gets incredibly repetitive when you're spending 20+ minutes on a puzzle. There are also only 19 puzzles, and I finished this game in a couple days. I would really give this game a neutral rating if that was an choice, but with how grating the music was and the incessant annoyance of finding the piece I wanted, I had to go with the negative option.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												The object is simple, grab jigsaw pieces floating in a pond along the top and side edge of the screen and assemble them into a picture in the middle. No timer. No real special abilities or upgrades. No contrived storyline. Just a neat little way to pass some time and look at some pretty pictures.Complexity is added along the way by increasing the piece count of new puzzles or by tackling a picture with fewer unique, easily identifiable features, but the most noticeable addition is the actual "cut" of the pieces with each new stage. Initially we're introduced to the more conventional shapes we'd expect to see jigsaw pieces to come in, but as you progress things are mixed up by having the interlocking segments of the pieces cut into shapes relevant to the picture for that puzzle. So, a watery picture might have pieces with interlocking segments in the shape of waves, for example, or another set might have tiny little temples or trees connecting each piece (though no Godzilla shapes are anywhere to be found, sadly). It's a really fresh take on an old formula that manages to hold your interest and keep you guessing for longer than it might have otherwise, but thankfully this really helps it to stand out.Another factor which makes it stand out is its presentation. Everything is presented with an air of tranquillity, from the constant gentle twangs of various Japanese string instruments, to the flow and splashing of water throughout that makes you want to go to the toilet at least once every puzzle set. Visually, there's no great flare or anything flashy going on, everything is clean and simple and in keeping with the overall style and tone of the game helping it make for a sedate and pleasant experience.During my time with the 21 puzzles (19 regular, unlockable sets, and 2 "bonus" sets that are unlocked from the beginning but don't seem to count towards overall progress, oddly), I only found myself having any difficulty with two of the sets, which was partly down to the finale's piece count, but also the lack of distinct features on their pictures, which is one of the few minor complaints I'd have with the game. I know that the colours and shapes in each picture scene has to be kept relatively similar throughout, otherwise you'd find every piece way too easily, but that doesn't mean the images have to be uninteresting. It would have been nice to assemble something that was a greater showcase of Japan and its culture, like pedestrians crossing the Shibuya intersection or some talking toilets or a schoolgirl underwear vending machine. But, instead, we have to be content with some temples or golf courses. Which are OK... I guess.Another minor gripe I had with it was the lack of a save feature. This isn't a problem for the easier early stages, but towards the end I could see it being a real issue for some as you might want to put an hour or so aside for a couple of the later, harder sets. Another, more pressing pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ though, was actually selecting the pieces from the pond. Again, this isn't so much a concern at the start, but by the end the pond is so full of moving pieces that grabbing one out of it becomes a real problem, to the extent that more often than not the piece I clicked on wouldn't be what came out and I'd appear to have some near by random piece instead, with me having to remove all the unwanted surrounding pieces before finally being able to get the one I wanted. A really strange oversight in an otherwise well made game.So, while it's not without its flaws, overall I really enjoyed my time with it. Full disclosure, I got the game free as part of a promotion on a bundle site, but even had I paid full price I'd still be happy with it. So if you've got a bit of spare time, a little patience, and some extra money to blow on a throwaway purchase, then I could easily point you towards this game to satisfy your crazy, insatiable jigsaw lust.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a couple of terrible projecting misconceptions, leading to creation of playable game - but only if you are really obstinate to complete it. This game is a typical jigsaw puzzle, rarely found on steam (if not unique). It includes around 20 different images. As suggested, all of them are japanese-themed. So, you complete puzzles, and by this you level up this tiny monk in bottom-left corner, from acolyte to someone who looks as if was abducted by aliens. Higher monk levels unlock more challenging puzzles, and he levels up when you complete all but one pictures from tier. Actual game is simple: pick piece from the pond and move it to right location, where it will be automatically locked. While regular jigsaw puzzles allow you to see the complete picture - here it's a bonus. You unlock a glance at the picture by placing pieces in correct locations. Unfortunately - even in the biggest puzzles you can use it 2-3 times.Stated at the beginning - this game is a collection of terrible projecting misconceptions. Firstly - while not a problem at smaller puzzles, try picking specified piece on more difficult ones. It's literally impossible. If the pieces are in swarm (and in this tiny pond they are almost all the time), game picks not the one you selected, but one closer to left top corner (this leads to exploit - check guides at game hub for more info on this). Second thing that bothered me terribly - game settings restart after you turn off the game. It's pain in the butt - mute the game (as the soundtrack and effects are quite annoying) everytime you play. Finally, due to limited access to big picture - some puzzles have to be completed by trying to fit each piece in every place (like in picture with cherry blooms).To sum up, this game is a great example of production with wasted potential. Jigsaw puzzles are scarce on Steam, so it's a shame that game like this is done so badly. Good things? If you try really hard, you may have fun. Plus, achievements are pretty easy to get - completing the game gives you all of them.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												The game isn't bad, but it's definitely not great. For being a game that is supposed to be 'zen', it has some features that make it pretty frustrating, particularly when doing puzzles with more pieces. At first, the game starts out being pretty relaxing, but as the game continues, the pieces floating around get smaller and smaller. This makes it hard to see what's on them sometimes, but that wouldn't be a problem in itself. The main problem is that once there gets to be more pieces, it's incredibly difficult to get the piece you actually want, especially before it floats under another clump of pieces. Even if the piece is on top, it feels like more often than not, whenever you click, it will select a random piece from within a centimeter or so radius. And forget about just dropping the piece and trying again - when you drop a piece, it takes itself and all the pieces around it back to the single spawn point in the water for the pieces. Soon, all the pieces will be all clustered together there and you'll basically just need to pile all the pieces up on your playing board if you want any of them, espeically a specific one. It would be nice to be able to actually select only the piece you are clicking on. It would also be very helpful not to have a piece go back to the spawn point when setting it down and have it actually stay where you set it. The ability to turn off the floating of the pieces would also be useful, particularly once they get pretty small. Another feature that this game is lacking that I've seen on free puzzle games is the ability for pieces to 'stick' to their neighboring pieces. Basically in this game, pieces only lock into place on the actual board. Even if you find two pieces that obviously go together but don't know where to put them yet, they will stay as separate pieces. It would be really nice if the pieces could click together and then be moved together. Maybe the developers didn't want to include this feature on purpose and I could see where having large chunks of pieces already stuck together would clutter up the board, but maybe it could be a feature that players could choose to turn on or off. Despite these annoying flaws, the game still does have some pros, including nice pictures and pretty neat edge styles that vary from puzzle to puzzle. It is a fun game, but it would be a lot less of a headache with the addition of the features I mentioned earlier. Because of the problems and the shortness of the game, I would have to NOT recomend the game at it's full price - $7 is too much when there are plenty of free puzzle games on other sites. If the game is ever on sale for $4 or less, then I would recommend picking it up if you're interested.

												A nice atmospheric jigsaw puzzle game. It has its share of drawbacks, though:1) Taking a piece out of the koi pond may be frustrating and their movement is confusing;2) Puzzle pieces are bound to the board - you can randomly drop a piece on its right place, but you can't connect them before that. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												Don't let the reviews fool you. This is not a good puzzle game.GOODThe puzzle pieces differ in size and shape from typical pieces. This adds a lot of variety to how connecting pieces can be approached.NEUTRALThe music is ok, but repetitive. Some of the sounds get annoying after a while.The art is mediocre and overrated.BADAlmost everything related to the 'river' system. A river containing all of the puzzle pieces runs along the outside edges of the board. The pieces float about in the river and are supposed to disperse throughout. The problem with this system is that pieces will often overlap and cover each other, making it impossible to find the piece that you're looking for. Grabbing and dropping a piece in the river will return it to an area at the left, instead of where you drop it. This can cause it to become buried under other pieces if accidentally dropped. It also causes cluttering around that area of the river, making it even harder to find pieces.Clicking seems to be a bit inaccurate. Clicking directly on a piece in the river will sometimes grab a nearby piece instead of the one you wanted.Picking a piece from the river will sometimes grab multiple pieces from the river. If this happens, all pieces are immediately dropped and returned to the left side of the river.The distribution of pieces throughout the river is extremely bad because of the above issues. The left side will always have all of the pieces while the top right will have only a handful.Pieces are placed into the puzzle by location, rather than by connecting them to one another. Finding two pieces that fit together effectively does nothing because they can't be connected, and leaving them on the board where they won't float covers up the locations. Returning them back to the river presents the issue of having to find the matching piece(s) again. This limits the number of strategies available for solving the puzzles and adds artificial difficulty.

												First impression of this game was very good. Nice puzzles. But after a while the controls are getting really annoying. The pieces are floating around the board and are constantly overlapping each other. This won't be a big problem if there are few pieces. But while you progress the pieces per puzzle are increasing, but not the space where they are floating around.In the last puzzles I couldn't pick a specific piece but got a random piece.Sadly there are some bugs. For example when you pick up a piece and drop it on another piece the will reset all to a "spawn point". Too bad if you teleport your piece away which you tried to reach.Another bug apears, when the pieces are floating around for a while. Especially when there are a huge amount of pieces. The get stuck. This sound nice, because you might pick them up easier. But they also stack while the are stuck. So you might not find your missing piece ;)Too bad you can't turn off the floating. A level editor to add own images would be nice. And if the pieces wouldn't be oriented correctly would give a new challenge to the puzzles. But only if you can pick up the piece you want to.Due to the bugs and frustration I only recommend it to you if you are patient. 5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												For small puzzles, this can be an entertaining enough time waster.  Unfortunately, the game has two major issues.First, puzzles are easy.  There is no piece rotation, which makes it rather obvious where pieces will go.  The distance that you can be off when you place a piece is rather forgiving, making it easy to place pieces by guessing.Second, the user interface is fatally flawed when playing larger puzzles, to a degree that large puzzles are exercises in frustration where you often simply cannot pick up the piece that you actually desire to pick up.  Unplaced pieces float in a pool around the board, and with large puzzles you have large clumps of numerous pieces.  The fatal flaw is that piece selection does not appear to be based on what the screen shows, and it appears to be nearly (if not entirely) impossible to pick up certain pieces if others are nearby.  One would think that the game would grab the top piece under the cursor, but it often doesn't.  Not only will it often refuse to grab the top piece of an overlapping stack, sometimes it appears to vacuum in nearby pieces that aren't even under the cursor.  You can know exactly which piece you want to pick up, but find it impossible to actually get the game to pick it up.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I am not sure about this downvote, because it still has some good points. Let's reviem them :It has a nice, relaxing soundtrack (however, it may stopfor no reason at any given time, and restart a few seconds later).Pieces have varied and interesting forms, and images to reform are great.Scaling difficulty (up to 350 pieces for the last one)And there are the flaws :The first, major flaw is the reason for my downvote : you may have noticed the moving pieces around the board. It is supposed to bring interactivity in the game. The reality is there, however. It is a hassle to find each piece, when you have found it, it is hard to follow and nearly impossible to pick (when you click on it, you pick a random near piece, the only way i have found is to isolate my piece (while it's moving) and then grab it). This problem intensifies as you go on to harder puzzles and the number of pieces increases. This functionality should be possible to disable, because it makes the whole experience frustrating.My last complain concerns the model of the puzzle. Instead of having a small window showing the complete puzzle (where you could, for example, zoom on it), you have a "power" which, when ready, will show you the model (superposed to the board), for a brief instant. Then, it disappears, and you're again missing it.To sum up, it's not actually a bad game, but it is a frustrating experience for one who, like me, is fond of jigsaw puzzles, thus, I don't recommend it, except if you would enjoy hunting (literally) for your pieces. However, the lack of good jigsaw puzzles on computer is the real ace for this game which contains 15 (or so) puzzles.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Pixel Puzzles lets you put pieces on a board until they form a picture, but fails to deliver a worthwhile jigsaw experience. Why? Well, two reasons, mostly.Firstly, the game doesn't care if you find two connecting pieces and put them together, which is how I (and most people) usually go about completing a jigsaw. Instead, it only cares if you put a piece in it's correct position on the picture, because yes, I absolutely knew that random piece went in that exact spot when it's closest neighbours are 6 pieces away.Secondly, while I actually like the little pond with pieces floating around, constantly shuffling, the fact that 9 times out of 10, I can't just click on the piece I want and actually get it, rather than another piece floating in the area, is extremely frustrating.Due to these two glaring design flaws, I cannot recommend this game. I'm sure there are some people who will be satisfied with it, but I'm also sure there are far better alternatives out there.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Most of my favorite games are action packed shooters filled with explosions and many different guns and complex role playing games with tons of story and dialog to become immersed in. So why do I recommend this game? For one point really: it's highly relaxing.Sometimes I want to just sit back, relax, and enjoy a game and maybe work my brain a little too. This game does just that. I got this game for free over at the IndieGala website, and when I first downloaded it, I didn't expect to like it at all, but I was completely wrong. I load up this game after a long day at school or doing homework for hours on end. It's a great way to escape stress and just let go. Most games I play require my full attention and for me to constantly be doing something. With no timer, Pixel Puzzles: Japan lets to solve beautiful puzzles centered around famous Japanese monuments and landscapes at your own pace.While the game is fairly simplistic, there are a few minor complaints. The first would be the higher level puzzles. As you progress, puzzle pieces become more and more strange. They're not your ordinary jigsaw pieces anymore, they're abstractly cut and hard to piece together. One way you can solve this is by starting with the sides and corners first.Second, and it is a small minor complaint, but I don't like how the pieces float around so much. I understand that they move around to make you have to look for them more, but I wish it was just a little bit slower. Anyways, I recommend this game to anyone looking for a relaxing and simple game to help take stress away from their lives. Sit back, grab a nice beverage and enjoy this wonderful little title, Pixel Puzzles: Japan.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game serves as a great time waster and offers good brain exorcise. It's quite nice and relaxing from the music to the subtle background sounds. Being a Japanese oriented game and being a big fan of Japanese culture myself, this earned extra points in my book. The puzzels can range from simple to difficult and offers enough challenge and content to have you sitting for hours on end. But of course this game isn't for everyone. It requires patience, the affinity towards jigsaw puzzles, and the ability to sit and focus. I can imagine this game wouldn't appeal towards those with who have bad attention/hyperactivity disorder. This is simply a game that works wonders when waiting and wasting time. I highly recommend this title and believe it's worth the price tag.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												This game doesn't manage to ruin the fun of putting jigsaw puzzles together, but it comes close with some terrible design choices:- When you place a piece in the correct spot, it locks in place... even if it's not connected to any neighboring pieces and it was just dump luck that you placed it there. This really kills your feeling of actually having any skill. There's also no visual indicator of which pieces are locked in their correct position, and which still need to be placed.- Pieces are ALWAYS oriented correctly with the puzzle. They never rotate.- If you find matching pieces, but don't know where they fit on the board yet, you can't keep them snapped together. You can't even put them beside each other somewhere out of the way, because there IS no "out of the way" area.- All the loose pieces move around in a koi pond beside the puzzle. You can take pieces out of the pond, but the only place to put them is on the puzzle board itself.- You can't just look at the box to see what the finished puzzle looks like. You have to correctly place a bunch of pieces to earn a five second glimpse of the finished puzzle.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Pixel Puzzles is exactly what it looks like: a jigsaw puzzle game.  Unused pieces float around the top and left of the puzzle in an appropriately-themed koi pond until you grab them and place them in the puzzle.  All pieces are oriented correctly with no rotation function.  Pieces will lock into place when close enough to their correct location no matter if adjacent pieces are in place or not.  Pieces will not lock together when not already placed in the correct location in the puzzle.Puzzles increase in difficulty as you progress through the game by increasing the complexity of the image and the number of pieces in the puzzle.  In the later puzzles the pond is so packed with pieces it's very difficult to locate a specific one and I took to just dragging random pieces out onto the board.  Each puzzle has different shapes for pieces and some of them make it very obvious when two pieces fit together.There is one large problem with the game however.  When picking up pieces, the game has a really nasty habit of picking up any piece EXCEPT the one you actually clicked on.  I've clicked on a piece that was completely alone in the pond and had the game grab one an inch away instead.  It gets quite frustrating seeing a piece and not being able to grab it before it floats off to get lost in the jumble of other pieces again.Despite that one major flaw, it's a competent jigsaw puzzle game which I don't believe there are many of on Steam.  I'd rate it an "indifferent" if I could.

Piece detection is abysmal. To make things worse all pieces are floating on the sides and above the picture makin search for the correct piece difficult. Some pictures are just stupid (flowers on the surface of the water - evey piece looks the same) or blurry (woods, walls) and it's hard to distinguish one from another.The fun part ends soon and you end up in 40+minutes of trial and error wishing it was over. I don't recommend.Piece you!

number of helpful: 1 of 12 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												All puzzles completed, including DLC to date.


All puzzles completed, including DLC. 
A Screenshot of Pixel Puzzles: Japan
By: Bogor Represent!




Pixel Puzzles is a nice jig-saw simulator. It has a wide range of puzzles with pastoral scenes of rural to ancient Japan that individually range from ho-hum to downright beautiful. The puzzles go from 'easy' 60pieces to what I would call 'journeyman' 250pieces.The setting is weirdly enough chinese... As you solve a puzzle, a chinese monk is pondering the I-ching and as you successfully place the pieces of your puzzle, he achieves enlightenment which gives you the chance to tap into this enlightenment to see a representation of the completed puzzle.The puzzle difficulty is tiered and you only unlock the next tier by levelling up your monk which you achieve by completing a set number of puzzles in a given tier. The way it is set up gives the impression that you can go your own way, but the only freedom you have is by deciding which puzzle in a tier you want to do first.The puzzle-screen is workmanlike and efficient, which I like. The screen's layout successfully focuses your attention to the part where you work on your puzzle. There's no information on the screen that can grab your attention away from the puzzle. No weird animated stuff, no dancing gibbies, no unasked for anime-crap (which the developers could easily have fallen for, I admire their restraint.).The music is light and unintrusive, though I must echo the complaints about the waterdrip garden-ornament. I never experienced the old sound-effect as it was patched before I bought Pixel Puzzles: Japan, but it still serves to shatter my concentration now and then. I would like to see an option to disable/enable the waterdrip garden-ornament so that players who don't want the sound-effect can play the game without it.Bordering the puzzle-table is a koi-pond in which the pieces float around. I guess the idea is that the player is rummaging around in there with their hands to grab a piece. I think it's a fun idea, but it doesn't translate well once in the game and trying to fish out the piece that you want can be a source of mild annoyance.Though the developers did went the extra mile here. For a cute laugh, catch the Koi and drop it on the puzzle-table. ^^The actual completing of the jig-saws is fundamentally flawed though. The pieces don't snap together, but they individually snap to the grid. This means that you can't make clusters like you can when you piece together a real jig-saw. I think that this is a glaring oversight.Secondly, it makes it extremely easy to cheese completion of a jig-saw as you can move a random piece around until it snaps in place, made even easier because the snap-to-grid mechanic is very forgiving. I have oftenly seen that I pushed a random piece aside only to have it snap to the grid!Another thing that missed the intended goal I guess is the form of the pieces. Though the developers probably thought that the sometimes outlandish shapes would make the puzzles harder, (did they recognize the problem with the snap-to-grid action too?), it actually achieves the opposite. I oftenly found myself looking for a specific shape rather than trying to find a piece that graphically matched the picture. The weird shapes make it too easy to piece together the bane of every jig-saw fanatic; large sections of clear blue sky.There is no scoring in Pixel Puzzles so completing a puzzle without using the monk's enlightenment goes unrewarded. Pixel Puzzles further does not block the computer from falling asleep, or to start the screensaver. Pixel Puzzler also doesn't believe in tooltips so it isn't readily clear what a button does unless you click on it to find out.While I do like the game an sich, as it does exactly what it says on the tin and nothing more or less, which with today's games is somewhat of a blessing as it has been a while since I've bought a game that did what is promised, I dislike the fact that when it comes to piecing together a jig-saw, Pixel Puzzler fails. The snap-to-grid action as opposed to fitting pieces together, coupled with the fact that with the weird shapes the piecing together is nothing but a 'find the weird shape that fits another weird shape affair', works to render the game alltogether too easy and robs the player of a challenge.Still a fun game that provides a good diversion and most certainly not overpriced. But it fails where it matters and that's a shame.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Let's set things straight: the game itself is a fine, simple, jigsaw puzzle game with a terrible, horribly frustrating addition. I'm unsure wether this is a regional tradition, or just a cruel joke on people who just want to get things done such as myself, but apparently the damn puzzle pieces flow in a river stream. A. River. Stream.So, whenever you set your eyes on the damn piece you've been looking for since the beginning of the puzzle, it WILL end up being either submerged, or dragged in a larger clump of pieces. Is this bad for everyone? Not sure. Is it making me wish i could drown myself in the rriver for the sake of never ever being forced to fish up pieces ever again? You bet."C'mon man, it can't be all this bad" you might say... Of course you never tried to get ahold of THAT single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ piece of puzzle for 2 minutes straight, as your mouse pointer hovers over it giggling at your feeble attempts. Because, of course, even if you're pointing the piece you want as if you were an italian pointer dog, it WILL fail. Repeatedly.If the whole point of the game is supposed to be relaxation and patience, may I say it fails kind of hard in both regards. Even the music, which is kind of interesting to listen to at first gets kind of unnerving after a few rounds of "catch the ducking piece" enchancing the whole "i hope this damn stream explodes and just leaves the damn pieces lying around the board" sensation.Ah, and "dulcis in fundu", you don't even get a damn clue on what the final image will look like ingame, so have fun trying to figure out where each piece belongs based purely on INSTINCT and, idk, supernatural powers of farseeing.I won't say anything about the puzzle selection menu, which is a game per se, in which the sole objective is to START THE GAME because I can't muster enough strength to bash it as well.I got this game for free, as a gift, and at first i did believe it was a gesture of friendship. Now i know i've got a mortal enemy out there, keeping an eye out for me, taking adavantage of my weak points.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												After about 7 hours and a half in this game I think I can write a proper review for it. It has both bad and good things but it's not unplayable, despite it's flaws.At first it was really fun, but as you play more and more you start to observe the problems with this game. And they are annoying: 1°) Lack of a save feature (last puzzle has 350 pieces and it took me about an hour to complete). If you are not patient enough, this game is not for you. You could Alt+Tab the game and do something else as a break from the puzzle, but I wouldn't do that to much (in the past I had some problems with some games on steam where I couldn't Alt+Tab because that would break the game).2°) The music is kind of nice, but it becames repetitive quite fast. You could try to mute it, but that would mute all sounds of the game and there is a little click sound when you place a piece in the right place which I found quite useful.3°) The images are nice, but have too many similar colors and aren't in HiRes. As the puzzles had more and more pieces it became quite hard to find the exact place where one piece would fit. It's even harder if you have a small screen (I played mine on a laptop and it was very painful and it placed a lot of strain on my eyes). The fact that it doesn't show you a big picture of what the puzzle should look like it doesn't help at all. It does have a little "hint" thing where it shows you the picture for a few seconds, but it puts the pieces over the actual picture and when you have many correct pieces it became even harder to find where you should put the other pieces (you can move the pieces normal when this "hint" it's activated). The "hint" button is charged at random when you place pieces correctly; you need 8 charges and you can get them all in a row or you can place 20 pieces and won't gain a single charge.4°) Picking the piece that you want from the pond can be really hard. Due to a glitch (or bad programming), if yhere are 2 consecutive pieces overlapped, it will ALWAYS give you the first piece (the left one) regardless of which is on top. This can actually help you to solve the puzzles (it is explained in guides how to do it), but it aomewhat kills the fun of doing a puzzle.It has some good parts too:1°) It has a decent variety of piece shapes, but sometimes this can be annoying.2°) The pieces are always oriented the right way (you can't rotate the pieces). It the beginning it may seem boring, but later on you will be grateful that you don't need to rotate the pieces.3°) You won't lose any of the pieces like you would with a classic jigsaw puzzle if you are not careful.4°) Achievements are not hard. 24 of the you will get just by finishing all puzzles. You also have to catch the fish which is moving around in the water (you will probably do this by mistake) and you must the fish in the Shishi-odoshi (I think that's what it's called that water thingy at the bottom left corner).Overall it's not a very bad game, but it's not worth 7 €/$. If you can get it in a bundle or on a sale (at least 66%) then you should give it a try (if you like jigsaw puzzles of course).

Posted: April 26, 2015
												While the game is extremely fun to play, it is really bad.Developers made almost no effort to deliver a good product, there are 2 hugely bad things about this game: the piece "fishing" system and the audio (both music and effects)As you can see from preview images, puzzle pieces float on a pond and you have to pick them up while they move/shuffle. In theory this should be good, but with a lot of pieces floating around (level 3+ puzzles) even if you click on the piece you want to pick up, you're offered other pieces instead, countless times. For me this is bad coding, plain and simple, because any tester can notice that and for sure the system is not supposed to work like that.Then there's the audio. Effects and music seems to have been recorded with a cell phone or something similar, I usually play with headphones and the background noise was terribly annoying.Many reviewers pointed out also that this game lacks a mid-puzzle save feature, but I have to say that it took at most one hour to complete puzzles (played 10h to complete 15 puzzles) and even if you're really bad with puzzles I can't see how you could spend more than idk, 2 hours trying to solve any of them, therefore I don't think the save feature is really something that is badly missing.So, again, I fully enjoyed playing this puzzle game, but because of the above I'd probably not recommend it to anyone, just buy a real physical puzzle instead.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												First of all, know that I'm not exactly a fan of jigsaw puzzles. I don't mind playing them sometimes, but I wouldn't consider myself being fond of them. If you are a big fan of those, maybe the points I'll make won't be negative for you. If that's the case, feel free to disregard my opinion.The main gimmick to this game is that the pieces move around. It wouldn't be so bad, but the way they made it, is incredibly frustrating. The pond where the pieces float is rather small. In the beginning it's not a problem, since the pieces are big, and there is not a lot of them. Later on though, pieces get smaller, and there's a whole lot more of them, but the pond stays the same size, which results in hundreds of puzzle pieces being on top of one another, in giant pile that you can't do anything about. And what's even worse, even if you somehow happen to see in that pile the exact piece you need at the moment, you won't be able to pick it up, unless there is no other piece next to it. That is because the controls are somehow broken, and the game will pick up any piece BUT the one that you are pointing at.Another big flaw is the lack of saving your progress. Later puzzles, combined with those broken and frustrating controls, can take several hours to complete, and you have to do that in one sitting or you'll be forced to start over.If you prefer it that way, great. But not everyone has the time and patience to do so, and such not even having the option to save is just bad design.Other than that, it's just a regular jigsaw puzzle with regular photographs of Japanese scenery, which is why I also feel like I've been lied to a little bit. With a title being "Pixel Puzzles" I expected, what else, pixel art, and I've got none of that.

Posted: May 15, 2015
												This game is a pretty straightforward collection of 21 jigsaw puzzles, with each puzzle depicting a different Japanese landmark.19 of the puzzles are structured into unlockable tiers: Tier 1 "Initiate" = six 60-piece puzzles, Tier 2 "Disciple" = five 112-piece puzzles, Tier 3 "Student" = four 153-piece puzzles, Tier 4 "Scholar" = three 220-piece puzzles, and Tier 5 "The All Knowing One" = one 350-piece puzzle.You start off the game with access to only the easiest group of puzzles, and must complete every challenge in that bracket to unlock the next set of difficulty. In addition to these tiered sets, there are also two separate bonus puzzles, available at any time from the golden section of the selection screen. They are in line with the higher difficulty settings, one because of its high piece count, and the other because of its unusual piece shapes. That's one thing I really like about this game, it plays with the overall shape of the pieces and with the interlocking edges. While there are a few puzzles that utilize the traditional silhouette, most of them mix it up with non-uniform sizing and unique key designs (spirals, arrows, prongs, pinking sheared, jagged scallops, etc).As far as the puzzle gameplay is concerned, the format is simple. You start out with a blank "sand garden" space where you build your puzzle, surrounded by an L-shaped koi pond that houses your unused pieces. You then use your mouse to pick up pieces from the pond and move them around the game board. When a piece is dropped close enough to the correct placement, a sound effect with play and it will snap into place. Overall, the game is as basic as it gets. You can change the colour of the sand, you can adjust the volume of the music, and you can switch between fullscreen and windowed, but beyond that there isn't any additional functionality:- You can't save your progress mid-puzzle. If you exit a puzzle screen, either to the main menu or to the desktop, you forfeit any work you have done so far (completed puzzles stay completed, however). - You can't turn off the water feature. The unused pieces in the koi pond are constantly floating, moving, and overlapping each other, and the pieces that appear on top of the pile are not always the ones that will be picked up by your mouse. This is not really a problem when you are dealing with 60 pieces, but on the harder difficulties you will spend half of your time trying to fruitlessly and frustratingly fish out the pieces you want from the pond.- There is no zoom mode. The board size remains the same regardless of piece count, so on the higher difficulty tiers it gets harder and harder to see the edges of the pieces.- You are unable to consult even a thumbnail of the image you are working on during a puzzle.- You can't build sections of the puzzle independently and then move those sections into place. - The 21 puzzles are always the same on every playthrough. While you are puzzling, you are entertained by occasional snippets of music. There are a handful of motifs programmed into the game, each one no more than 10-30 seconds long, and each one sounding like the introduction to a song rather than a complete melody. Sometimes you will hear a refrain and then 1-2 minutes of silence. Sometimes the game will play a medley of snippets back-to-back. Sometimes the game will play the same snippet back-to-back. It's possible that the music is somehow tied-in to what actions you are doing, but I couldn't discern any predictable pattern or rationale. Honestly, the snippets themselves were enjoyable, atmospheric, and in-line with the cultural aesthetic of the game, but their length, and the inconsistency of how they were played, was distracting and annoying. (What the music thought it sounded like: "Nostalgic touches of music, liltingly carried on the wind, falling on your ears like leaves falling from trees..." What the music actually sounded like: "A child haltingly and repetitively trying to learn shamisen in the apartment next door.")There are 26 achievements for the game, which basically boil down to "play all the puzzles and mess with the fish." You will automatically unlock 99% of them in one playthrough.TL;DR - If you are just looking for a casual and basic jigsaw game with a good number of puzzles, creative piece designs, and featuring postcard-quality images from Japan, then this is 100% the game for you. However, if you are looking for a high-challenge, high-frill game with adaptive puzzles, sectional construction, zoomable game boards, a rocking soundtrack, and advanced save features, then this is simply not going to meet your expectations. For what it is, and what it claims to be, it does a pretty decent job. I received this game for free as part of a bundle, and got 11 hours of mostly-fun gameplay out of it. I would give it a 7/10.

Posted: October 11, 2015
												"Pixel Puzzles: Japan" is a fine timewaster.Do you like puzzles? Excellent. Do you like Japanese culture? It's certainly not necessary but if you like it it's even better.There are 21 puzzles in total to finish with photorealistic motifs mostly of Japanese buildings and gardens. First, of course, the puzzles are very easy. But don't underestimate the last ones. They can really steal the time as their puzzle pieces become smaller, more and more special in shape, the motifs also seem to be unclearer to see. But all in all they're good to solve.So the gameplay is just dragging pieces to certain places until they automatically snap in. But it can be a pain in the a... to grab a very certain piece you want because they all float into each other (like on water) and it also turns into a "catch me if you can" game. Just to prepare you for possible little moments of frustration.The graphics are not especially beautiful but okay. When it comes to music there's only one Japanese instrumental song played. It's nice but soon you won't wanna listen to the same song over and over again. So either mute the music or do so and hold your own (Japanese) background music on standby.I recommend this game for relaxing puzzle sessions (I, for example, enjoyed this a lot after work) and would like to try out the other puzzle games by Decaying Logic someday.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												Recently I was extremely bored and looking for games in my massive steam library to get 100% achievements on. I ran across Pixel Puzzles: Japan which I picked up from some bundle offer at one point and installed it. My girlfriend came home from work and I asked her to play a video game with me, which is at times very hard to get her to do. She agreed and I decided to fire up this game, as she is quite the puzzle-holic and loves jigsaw puzzles. After hours of playtime, we got all of the achievements in the game and had a good time doing it. Pixel Puzzles: Japan is basically a set of normal jigsaw puzzles on PC. There are 19 different puzzles in the game, which get incrementally larger the farther you go. Putting together the puzzles is fairly simple and works well overall. One large annoyance we experienced consistently is attempting to grab a piece from the "pond", where the pieces you have yet to put down float around until you grab them. Whenever you try to grab a piece floating with others, the majority of the time the game will not grab the correct piece, causing frustration. This can be remedied by just pulling out a bunch of pieces and throwing them on your board, until you can grab the right one. As you place pieces in the correct spot, they lock onto the board to aid in speeding things up as well. The puzzles are all based on Japanese locations and themes, hence the name of the game.Pixel Puzzles: Japan was a nice game to play over a few evenings to 100% achievements, and I recommend it if you can find it at a budget price.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Let's set things straight: the game itself is a fine, simple, jigsaw puzzle game with a terrible, horribly frustrating addition. I'm unsure wether this is a regional tradition, or just a cruel joke on people who just want to get things done such as myself, but apparently the damn puzzle pieces flow in a river stream. A. River. Stream.So, whenever you set your eyes on the damn piece you've been looking for since the beginning of the puzzle, it WILL end up being either submerged, or dragged in a larger clump of pieces. Is this bad for everyone? Not sure. Is it making me wish i could drown myself in the rriver for the sake of never ever being forced to fish up pieces ever again? You bet."C'mon man, it can't be all this bad" you might say... Of course you never tried to get ahold of THAT single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ piece of puzzle for 2 minutes straight, as your mouse pointer hovers over it giggling at your feeble attempts. Because, of course, even if you're pointing the piece you want as if you were an italian pointer dog, it WILL fail. Repeatedly.If the whole point of the game is supposed to be relaxation and patience, may I say it fails kind of hard in both regards. Even the music, which is kind of interesting to listen to at first gets kind of unnerving after a few rounds of "catch the ducking piece" enchancing the whole "i hope this damn stream explodes and just leaves the damn pieces lying around the board" sensation.Ah, and "dulcis in fundu", you don't even get a damn clue on what the final image will look like ingame, so have fun trying to figure out where each piece belongs based purely on INSTINCT and, idk, supernatural powers of farseeing.I won't say anything about the puzzle selection menu, which is a game per se, in which the sole objective is to START THE GAME because I can't muster enough strength to bash it as well.I got this game for free, as a gift, and at first i did believe it was a gesture of friendship. Now i know i've got a mortal enemy out there, keeping an eye out for me, taking adavantage of my weak points.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												After about 7 hours and a half in this game I think I can write a proper review for it. It has both bad and good things but it's not unplayable, despite it's flaws.At first it was really fun, but as you play more and more you start to observe the problems with this game. And they are annoying: 1°) Lack of a save feature (last puzzle has 350 pieces and it took me about an hour to complete). If you are not patient enough, this game is not for you. You could Alt+Tab the game and do something else as a break from the puzzle, but I wouldn't do that to much (in the past I had some problems with some games on steam where I couldn't Alt+Tab because that would break the game).2°) The music is kind of nice, but it becames repetitive quite fast. You could try to mute it, but that would mute all sounds of the game and there is a little click sound when you place a piece in the right place which I found quite useful.3°) The images are nice, but have too many similar colors and aren't in HiRes. As the puzzles had more and more pieces it became quite hard to find the exact place where one piece would fit. It's even harder if you have a small screen (I played mine on a laptop and it was very painful and it placed a lot of strain on my eyes). The fact that it doesn't show you a big picture of what the puzzle should look like it doesn't help at all. It does have a little "hint" thing where it shows you the picture for a few seconds, but it puts the pieces over the actual picture and when you have many correct pieces it became even harder to find where you should put the other pieces (you can move the pieces normal when this "hint" it's activated). The "hint" button is charged at random when you place pieces correctly; you need 8 charges and you can get them all in a row or you can place 20 pieces and won't gain a single charge.4°) Picking the piece that you want from the pond can be really hard. Due to a glitch (or bad programming), if yhere are 2 consecutive pieces overlapped, it will ALWAYS give you the first piece (the left one) regardless of which is on top. This can actually help you to solve the puzzles (it is explained in guides how to do it), but it aomewhat kills the fun of doing a puzzle.It has some good parts too:1°) It has a decent variety of piece shapes, but sometimes this can be annoying.2°) The pieces are always oriented the right way (you can't rotate the pieces). It the beginning it may seem boring, but later on you will be grateful that you don't need to rotate the pieces.3°) You won't lose any of the pieces like you would with a classic jigsaw puzzle if you are not careful.4°) Achievements are not hard. 24 of the you will get just by finishing all puzzles. You also have to catch the fish which is moving around in the water (you will probably do this by mistake) and you must the fish in the Shishi-odoshi (I think that's what it's called that water thingy at the bottom left corner).Overall it's not a very bad game, but it's not worth 7 €/$. If you can get it in a bundle or on a sale (at least 66%) then you should give it a try (if you like jigsaw puzzles of course).

Posted: April 3, 2015
												A perfect little game to play while waiting for a download to finish or something like that. A nice theme, some pretty challenging puzzles later on, but there are just too many small annoyances that make you think: 'why didn't the developers fix this? They surely must have played their own game?'These are the things that make a possibly calming game into an occasional teeth grinder:Puzzles can't be saved mid-game. So when you have been playing Pixel Puzzles while waiting for something to finish downloading you can't save your current state of the puzzle. This destroys the whole casual nature of the game. It's either finish the puzzle or start the puzzle over the next time. And with pretty masive puzzles in later levels, that's just not cool.The puzzle pieces literally float around a fish pond that surround half the puzzle field. In later levels the amount of pieces increases. This also makes the puzzles pieces very, very small. It becomes quite hard to see them and properly discern them from one another. And to add to the problems with this...The mouse pointer is incredibly inaccurate. Imagine wanting to click-drag a puzzle piece from the pond onto the table, and having to click six or seven times, because the pointer keeps picking up pieces besides the one you want. Oh, and remember that the pieces float around? Yeah, terribly annoying.The sound is supposed to add to the meditative, monastery-like atmosphere of the game. Too bad the sound quality is pretty low and several sound effects have a slight static to them when they play.For €6,99 there's just too many obvious things unnecessarily working against the player. Around €2 would be acceptable and I then would also recommend the game, because the puzzles are challenging and have a pretty big 'just one more puzzle before bed' feel about them.

Posted: April 3, 2015
Introduction: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a casual game in which you solve a variety of jigsaw puzzles by clicking and dragging a puzzle piece from the river surrounding the board to where it belongs on the board itself. While the game does several things correctly, it ultimately has too many problems for me to truly recommend it. It is a decent game, but falls just short of greatness.Gameplay:  Being a jigsaw puzzle game, there is only a certain amount of gameplay to be expected. You solve the jigsaw puzzles by clicking on a puzzle piece from a flowing river around the edge of the board to the board itself. It's simple; however there are a few annoyances. The river constantly moves the puzzle pieces around, which is quite neat for the smaller puzzles. However, the puzzle pieces bounce off each other and the edges of the river. This results in puzzle pieces being clumped together on the larger puzzles, even getting stuck in corners. In one such puzzle, there were about seven puzzle pieces stuck in a corner, overlapping each other. Picking the puzzle piece you want in this mess is an annoyance as the click detection seems a bit off. Despite my mouse being directly over the desired puzzle piece, I would often pick up the puzzle piece just beside it, over and over. Even though I knew the piece I wanted, I struggled against the game to actually get it. Dropping a puzzle piece back in the river spawns it to the bottom left part of the river instead of the spot you dropped it, which further adds to the "clumping" issue.For the small puzzles, the river is actually quite a refreshing concept. For the larger puzzles, it quickly turns into an annoyance, making it take much longer than it should to solve the puzzle.Upon correctly putting a puzzle piece in the correct spot on the board, you will randomly get a piece of the yin and yang symbol. Upon fully completing the symbol, you will be able to temporarily see the completed puzzle on the board and the pieces you have already placed. This is an interesting concept, but it ultimately felt...a bit pointless. In most cases, I felt like this made it even more difficult to see what I had placed and what was left. I only found the feature useful on the last puzzle. It is also random when you get a piece of the symbol; however it happened often enough to not be an issue. It may help solve the puzzle, but I feel it could have been done better.There are 21 puzzles in the game to complete, which is very reasonable for the price tag. Not all of the puzzles are available to complete right way, however. The player must complete the smaller puzzles to unlock the larger ones. This gives a sense of progression, which is interesting for this genre of game. There is actually an, albeit brief, cut-scene that plays showing the player's avatar "levelling up". Completing every puzzle in the game took approximately 9 hours. The puzzle sizes range from 60 pieces to 350 pieces.Art & Graphics:  The game captures a Japanese feel to it quite well. All of the puzzles carry a Japanese theme, and the board the player assembles the puzzle on also has this same theme. The graphics are simple - about what you would expect for a puzzle game. I had no difficulty running the game on a 1920x1080 monitor while also using dual monitors.Sound:  Unfortunately, the game only has one music track that plays both on the main menu of the game, and when assembling puzzles. This music track carries a Japanese theme and is relaxing for a time; however I had to disable the music after completing a few puzzles as it got tiring. Besides the music, there is not much other sound to speak of. There is no sound that plays when inserting a puzzle piece to the correct place unless it randomly gives you a piece of the yin and yang symbol. There is no sound when the player "levels up" their avatar. There is no sound when completing the puzzle. The game feels very quiet. As a result, I hope you love the one music track that plays, or you had best play your own music in the background.Replay Value:  Once you complete every puzzle, there is no incentive to do so again. Every puzzle has the exact same pieces every time and your avatar only levels up to a certain point. While the developers have added two free puzzles to the game in the past (the game originally had 19), it is very unlikely more puzzles will be added. There are 26 achievements for the game, although nearly all of them are only for completing the puzzles.Prismatic Complaints:  There is no save feature for the game. If you exit out of the puzzle, your computer crashes, or your power goes out: you are out of luck. Completing a puzzle saves your progress of course, however your progress on the puzzle itself is not saved. This makes it a difficult game to play casually, as you either have to complete a puzzle in one sitting or leave the game running to finish it later. There is also no Steam cloud support.Closing: While Pixel Puzzles: Japan does several things right and tries new things, it ultimately falls a bit short of greatness. The game is fun, and I enjoyed my time on it, however the annoyances are a bit too frequent. The lack of many sounds, as well as the lack of saving, also brings the game down a bit. If you're a fan of jigsaw puzzles, you will likely have a good time, but be frustrated by the annoyances the game has.

Posted: August 7, 2015
												I love doing jigsaw puzzles but I never thought to see if there were any digital versions on Steam. I found this during a Humble Bundle sale and thought I might as well try it for less than $2. It certainly hasn't made me want to throw out all my real jigsaw puzzles, but for what I paid for it, it's a fun distraction.Pros:-I like the music and sound of the game. It's very minimalist and zen, very traditionally Japanese. It's nicely relaxing for a game like this.-The images are all Japan related, so if you like that kind of thing, you'll like these.-The "level up" aspect is sort of neat, levelling up your little monk to do harder and harder puzzles.Cons:-The puzzle pieces floating around in the koi pond is kind of annoying. It makes it hard to see what you have left or to spot corner and edge pieces without. Plus picking up a piece and dropping it drops it in a specified location where that piece 'spawns', not where you dropped it.-Pieces can't be put together on their own, they have to be dropped into their space on the board. So you can't put together a section separately and then move it into the main board when you can. This also means that just moving a piece onto the board to help find its space can sometimes accidentally have you drop it right onto its spot without meaning to where it snaps in, which spoils it a little bit.-The pieces are all always right side up. You don't have to rotate them or anything like that.-The pieces aren't 'standard' puzzle shapes, they're all strange little curves and blobs.The game's certainly not bad, but I wouldn't recommend paying full price for it. And if you're a jigsaw puzzle 'snob' like I sort of am then the experience is pretty different. But for a cheap price and an hour or so of relaxing with a warm drink, this is perfectly fine.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												I really do like this game, but it has some major bugs. Out of the 14 puzzles I have completed, I've had to restart three when I only had one piece left to place. I had to restart twice due to the final piece not fitting correctly. One needed to be rotated and the second time the piece shape needed to be flipped (the negative size needed to be on the right and the positive side needed to be on the left). The third time, there wasn't a final piece, the game somehow made one piece just disappear. I grabbed the fish a million times to try and see it if was stuck, searched the river and corners, I clicked all over the completed puzzle to make sure it wasn't just hidden on the board, but alas, it was nowhere. I also find it to be frustrating when trying to grab a specific piece and it grabs every single piece other than the one I have selected. I usually get around this by only selecting pieces that are on the top since they are not as crowded. I cannot recommend this to anyone who is a completionist, like me, due to the fact that sometimes you cant complete the puzzle unless you restart. I still purchased this despite a review saying they didn't recommend this, but it was less than a dollar. However, once I experienced these bugs, I found myself wondering how in the world something could be so badly designed that pieces dont fit/ are missing. Either way, I think this is a great idea and it is relaxing (until you experience said bugs). I just wish they would fix the bugs and then it will be a great, simple, and cheap game.

Posted: March 18, 2015
												A surprisingly nice way to pass the time and take a break from all your action, MMO, FPS, RPG, rogue-like, dungeon-crawler what-have-yous. The atmosphere, music, and puzzles are quite immersive and the go-at-your-own-pace (non-timed) element makes this great for young and old alike.That said, there are some obvious flaws within Pixel Puzzles - Japan:There is no mid-level save feature. This is the biggest issue that can easily flip a recommendation. The beginning levels are easy enough to sit through in one sitting, taking anywhere between 5-20 minutes each (or more if you're really taking your time). Once the puzzles get harder (and the amount of pieces start increasing), the probability of you wanting to take a break will shoot up. Your only options for taking a breather will be either to 1. Tab out of the game and leave it running until you want to come back to it or 2. Close out of the game and restart the entire level. Both options are pains in their own ways.Puzzle-fishing can sometimes be more annoying than the puzzle itself. Puzzle pieces float around in a pond that borders your puzzle mat (it's actually a zen garden -- fitting). There is no pause feature for the pond so you're left trying to grab the piece you want in the middle of all the others. Clicking or click-hold-releasing a piece over the pond will make it poof and teleport somewhere else in the water. When you've been clearing out a pile and you accidentally clear out the piece you want as well.. it's a little frustrating. It's easily avoidable if you're not a dolt like me.Possible catch-release bug? Not quite sure if it's my laptop/touchpad/mouse but it sometimes takes me a couple of clicks to pick up pieces. Some of them get "stuck" on the board (when they're not in the right place) and takes several tries to grab. I'm running Windows 8.1 in case the problem's on my end.Cons taken into consideration, I would still recommend this game if gifted or purchased on a discount. I don't think the retail price is worth dealing with the snags that may make you want to rage-quit (or completely abandon the game) but it's a good little single-player casual to fiddle around with.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												So... What to say about 'Pixel Puzzles: Japan'... It's a puzzle game! No rotating blocks... No floating pills... No exploading candies, gems or animals... But an actual jigsaw puzzle game. Now if it were just that, my review would be done now, but there's more. The puzzles are lovely and are in various shapes, cuts and sizes.The goal of the game is simple... Complete a puzzle and obtain a golden puzzle piece for your monk so that he may ascend to a higher state... and ultimately, puzzles with more pieces. As you set about the task putting together the puzzles, the pieces not on the board yet, float around on the surface of a pond and you have to try and scoop up the piece you'd like. If you toss a piece back into the water, you can sink a number of pieces foor a moment in hopes of making it easier to grab the piece you do want... And that's it.It's a nice, simple and relaxing game, set to soothing oriental music; perfect for the casual gamer that enjoys a slow paced game or the hardcore garmer looking to find that calm before the storm of bullets and rampaging zombies... among other things.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												After completing all the puzzles and therefore earning all the achievements, I feel competent enough to tell you about this game.But man, it sure is hard to review it. Why is it hard, you ask? Well, if you came here to get a game that allows you to piece together jigsaw puzzles, it's exactly what it is. But still, even a simple game like this can have numerous issues that will ruin your experience with it. And this one is no exception.The first thing and the most obvious thing is the fact that you can't piece together one small part of the puzzle and keep it somewhere to the side so you can use it later, after you make some progress on the "big picture". Every piece has its designated place on the board, and you can only put them there one at a time, after which you can't move them anymore.The second thing is the fact that those puzzle pieces float around in the water that surrounds the board. Why is that a problem? Well, on the first few 60-piece puzzles, it isn't. You can get most of the pieces easily or with just a bit of stressful effort. But when you get to those bigger puzzles, then you'll notice this game's main flaw - the inability to properly grab a piece. Whatever could that mean? It means that the game grabs EVERY. SINGLE. PUZZLE. PIECE. AROUND. THE. ONE. THAT. YOU. WANTED. BUT. NOT. THE. ONE. THAT. YOU. WANTED. It is so frustrating that you will be tearing your eyes out after not grabbing your piece for the 20th time. I'm not even kidding, one time I counted how many tries it would take to get the piece that I wanted, and I stopped counting after I had passed twenty.But wait, that's not all. How could it be all? It seems that the developers really wanted to make you feel the water that the pieces float in, so they tried to make this "splash" feature where, after you drop an unwanted puzzle piece into the water right above some other floating pieces, those floating pieces that were "underneath" the one you dropped will get moved to some other place in the water. And that is really annoying, because you'll always be grabbing onto unwanted pieces, and when you accidentally let go of your mouse click, the piece that you wanted will be lost within the maze of floating pieces that all look alike.And get this - that piece-grab recognition failure occurs in every puzzle but the last one. The last puzzle is pretty smooth and it just makes me wonder why it couldn't be like that before. It's like the developer knew how to make the piece-grabbing responsive, but decided to troll you the whole time until the last puzzle.As far as music goes, I guess it's okay if you're into that whole Japan-style culture, but I still think it could have been much better. An occasional oriental sound or two with long pauses in between doesn't make a relaxing soundtrack, it just manages to surprise you every time because you totally forget there's even a soundtrack in this game.The puzzles mostly feature japanese architecture, so if you like that too, I think you'll be satisfied. I myself would have preferred a puzzle game featuring animals, to be honest, but that's just my misanthropy speaking. (lol)Oh, and each puzzle has its pieces cut into different shapes, so that's pretty cool! It helps keep each puzzle fresh, in my opinion.But ultimately, I'm supposed to tell you if you should give your money for this game, and I believe you shouldn't. Seven euros is simply too much for a game with this many flaws. I'm glad I got it for free on indiegala, so if you didn't get it there while it was still available and you simply feel the need to get it, at least buy it on a sale or in a bundle. Those seven euros can be spent on better things, whether here on Steam, or in the offline world.
