Posted: March 25, 2016
												Before Pixel Puzzles: Japan, I was nothing. I loved a girl, but she didn't like me. I wasn't cool enough for her. But then I got this game. I asked her to come to my house:-Hey! Wanna come over my house?-Why?-Ummm to watch a movie or play videogames, I guess.-No ♥♥♥♥ing way. I'm not gonna do it.-But I got Pixel Puzzles: Japan!-What time do you want me to come over your place?-Idk, around 7pm? Is that fine?-Yeah, sure!I showed her the game and she told me to have sex with her. I said "hell yeah". Thought it was the best day of my life. But a few days later, she brought a friend of hers as well. We were officially in a relationship and it was awesome! Thanks to Pixel Puzzles: Japan, not only did I have a gorgeous girlfriend and awesome sex every day, but we occasionally had threesomes as well.Time had passed, it had been 1-2 months, and I kept playing Pixel Puzzles: Japan. I had become addicted to Pixel Puzzles: Japan. All I was thinking was Pixel Puzzles. All I was dreaming was Pixel Puzzles. All I could see, hear, feel, smell, taste, was Pixel Puzzles. My girlfriend started to hate that game, because I prefered Pixel Puzzles over her companion. But I was fine. She wasn't. So, we broke up. Two days later, I lost my job. I got kicked out of my house because I had no money to pay the rent 1 month later. I'm currently living in a basement in London where I get WiFi from a neighbour. I haven't slept for 1 whole week. I cannot do anything. Pixel Puzzles: Japan became the love of my life. This game made me realise the meaning of life. Or, to be exact, this game is the meaning of life. I am now raising money to visit the Great Pixel Puzzle Monk in Japan. It's a dream coming true. Your help will be appreciated. Help me make the world a better place. Believe in Pixel Puzzles: Japan. Amen.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												I really do like this game, but it has some major bugs. Out of the 14 puzzles I have completed, I've had to restart three when I only had one piece left to place. I had to restart twice due to the final piece not fitting correctly. One needed to be rotated and the second time the piece shape needed to be flipped (the negative size needed to be on the right and the positive side needed to be on the left). The third time, there wasn't a final piece, the game somehow made one piece just disappear. I grabbed the fish a million times to try and see it if was stuck, searched the river and corners, I clicked all over the completed puzzle to make sure it wasn't just hidden on the board, but alas, it was nowhere. I also find it to be frustrating when trying to grab a specific piece and it grabs every single piece other than the one I have selected. I usually get around this by only selecting pieces that are on the top since they are not as crowded. I cannot recommend this to anyone who is a completionist, like me, due to the fact that sometimes you cant complete the puzzle unless you restart. I still purchased this despite a review saying they didn't recommend this, but it was less than a dollar. However, once I experienced these bugs, I found myself wondering how in the world something could be so badly designed that pieces dont fit/ are missing. Either way, I think this is a great idea and it is relaxing (until you experience said bugs). I just wish they would fix the bugs and then it will be a great, simple, and cheap game.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												The game is fun until you get to the highest levels. Then it becomes extremely annoying.  The puzzle pieces you want become impossible to grab from the pool of the unused ones - I had to click like ten times until I got the one I wanted (I think this is a bug - they sort of float around, moving constantly, passing over each other, but even though the one I wanted was on the top, clicking on the pile kept giving me the bottom ones that I didn't want... and by the time I got through the pile, others floated over the one I wanted again. EXTREMELY annoying.)Overall, the game has nice environment, a few jokes incorporated into it, not-so-special pictures as puzzles (I didn't find the photographies used particularly beautiful - they look like snapshots a tourist might take when visiting Japan), and no option to save your unfinished work.  Overall, I'd give it about 45% - it could have been worse, but there are better games to spend money on out there.

Posted: March 22, 2015
												This is a pretty good game.  It took 7.8 hours to complete the entire game (19 puzzles) and get all the achievements.  There is nothing wrong with the game technically and it works perfectly.  The pictures that make up the puzzle are great.  There is a lot of variety in puzzle cuts.  The only negatives are the music and grabbing the pieces in the river during larger puzzles.  The music is redundant so I turned it off and listened to the radio instead.  The game has all of the puzzle pieces floating in a river above and to the left of the puzzle area.  When it gets crowded with a lot of pieces in the more difficult, larger puzzles at the end of the game, you very rarely grab the piece you are clicking on.  Gets annoying and adds more time to the puzzle.  Also, when you grab a piece and don't need it and drop it back in the river it doesn't land where you put it and just disappears and gets mixed up with the rest of the pieces again (so you can't set a piece to the side for later).If you like jigsaw puzzles you'll like this game and for the price you can't go wrong.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												Oh my word the design choices on this one. Sounds fun and mellow enough, just a classic fit the pieces together puzzle like your grandpa did on the table top. Your grandpa could always look at the box to see the picture, but I still can't seem to figure out how I made the picture pop up that one time. Then there are the absolutely tiny puzzle pieces floating in a pond. Floating all over each other, and generally being a nuisance to click, or find the one piece you want. I've had to click 10 times, randomly getting other nearby pieces, before finally getting the one I want. The pictures themselves are pretty, but several just don't have enough definition between areas of the puzzle. It turns them into a random "does this fit here?" mess of trial and error. Then I haven't found a way to save in the middle of a puzzle, you know like grandpa leaving it on the kitchen table til he can get around to it again. If you want to tell me how to save, or look up the puzzle, that's awesome, but it's something the game needs to explain in some clear way itself. Even better would be giving me some static place I can sort the damn puzzle pieces, without just tossing all of them on the puzzle board, where some will obviously randomly click into the right place. That's not how I want the game to work.In short, something seemingly meant to be soothing is for me entirely aggravating.2/5

Posted: January 2, 2016
												The puzzles are fine, but the game is not. There are too many faults with this game for me to recommend it to anyone.You cannot save your progress if you want to close the game. Puzzles always start from the beginning. It is easy to reset a puzzle, because the game does not ask you for confirmation before resetting a puzzle.Puzzle pieces which haven't been kept on the board yet keep moving around needlessly, which is okay for puzzles with big pieces, i.e. not a feature that improves the game, but not one which makes it frustrating either. However, if you try playing a puzzle with tiny pieces, you will repeatedly pick up pieces that you do not want to use, and as soon as you drop a piece back, it disappears under your mouse, and reappears somewhere else on the 'pond' around the puzzle board. I've had sessions where I picked up 10-15 wrong pieces in a row because the correct one was flowing under a ton of wrong pieces, and then I was so in the flow of picking and dropping wrong pieces that I picked up and dropped back the piece I wanted to use, which then immediately disappeared and went to some other part of the pond, getting lost in the flood of pieces moving around, not to be found again anytime soon.You can't fit puzzle pieces together even if you know that they will eventually end up next to each other. The only way to snap two puzzle pieces together is to put both of them in their correct spots on the board. So, the game makes it hard to work on multiple parts of the puzzle at the same time, unless you can figure out exactly where in the board those parts will fit.Overall: Stay away. This is at best a bad and often frustrating implementation of what is supposed to be a relaxing table top activity.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												First off, I love jigsaw puzzles, so it always interests me when there's a jigsaw puzzle title so I can see what kind of gimmicks they put into the software. In this one, you have all the pieces floating around randomly in the water and when you put enough specific pieces in place, you can get a brief preview of what the finished image is supposed to be.For most of the puzzles, this is all fine and dandy. However, when you get to the last few puzzles that are over 200 pieces, trying to find that piece that you're looking for floating in that mess is quite annoying. And then, I don't know how, but somehow the computer knows what piece you're going after and gives you every other piece BUT the one you're going after. It'll even give you a piece that's not where you're clicking, only near it.Another thing that I didn't care for in this title is the method that the pieces snap into place. On this one, the pieces snap to the board. I much prefer that the pieces snap to each other since it makes it easier to see if you got any pieces laying around on the board when you're wondering what the hell you did with the last few pieces.One thing I really did like about this was the interesting ways the pieces were cut. It made the puzzles seem more unique and fun.It took me about 13 hours to go through all of this. My overall rating lands just on the not recommended side.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												A jigsaw puzzle game consists of essentially two things: picking peices up, and setting them down. Some how this game manages to screw up both.The snap to grid is ridiculously loose, and does not require *any* adjacent peices, making it a common occurrence to set a piece down and have it magically jump into a position you had not yet identified. Brute forcing tricky areas by picking-up-dropping-picking-up-dropping until it snaps is way to easy to do... trains you quickly to play by trial-and-error not analysis.If that was all, I'd still give this game a thumbs up. Sadly, the peice-selection interface is broken beyond hope. You spot a peice, you mouse directly over it, you click, and... you get randomly one of the thirty closest peices. On the latter puzzles it is virtually impossible to pick up a specific peice without 10-20 attempts. I can't express how frustrating this is. Completely game breaking. Clearly this was not play tested.tl;dr game with real potential sadly broken by unusable interface.

Posted: March 25, 2016
												Before Pixel Puzzles: Japan, I was nothing. I loved a girl, but she didn't like me. I wasn't cool enough for her. But then I got this game. I asked her to come to my house:-Hey! Wanna come over my house?-Why?-Ummm to watch a movie or play videogames, I guess.-No ♥♥♥♥ing way. I'm not gonna do it.-But I got Pixel Puzzles: Japan!-What time do you want me to come over your place?-Idk, around 7pm? Is that fine?-Yeah, sure!I showed her the game and she told me to have sex with her. I said "hell yeah". Thought it was the best day of my life. But a few days later, she brought a friend of hers as well. We were officially in a relationship and it was awesome! Thanks to Pixel Puzzles: Japan, not only did I have a gorgeous girlfriend and awesome sex every day, but we occasionally had threesomes as well.Time had passed, it had been 1-2 months, and I kept playing Pixel Puzzles: Japan. I had become addicted to Pixel Puzzles: Japan. All I was thinking was Pixel Puzzles. All I was dreaming was Pixel Puzzles. All I could see, hear, feel, smell, taste, was Pixel Puzzles. My girlfriend started to hate that game, because I prefered Pixel Puzzles over her companion. But I was fine. She wasn't. So, we broke up. Two days later, I lost my job. I got kicked out of my house because I had no money to pay the rent 1 month later. I'm currently living in a basement in London where I get WiFi from a neighbour. I haven't slept for 1 whole week. I cannot do anything. Pixel Puzzles: Japan became the love of my life. This game made me realise the meaning of life. Or, to be exact, this game is the meaning of life. I am now raising money to visit the Great Pixel Puzzle Monk in Japan. It's a dream coming true. Your help will be appreciated. Help me make the world a better place. Believe in Pixel Puzzles: Japan. Amen.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												What I thought would be a relaxing pass-time, is actually the most unintuitive jigsaw puzzle simulator game I've ever played. Almost everything about this game goes against everything I've ever known about putting together puzzles. For instance, y'know when you get two seperate pieces that fit together? I'm not sure about you, but my first instinct would be to fit them together. Unfortunatley, the way the game works, is that each individual piece can only snap into place once it's directly where it needs to be in the picture. So instead of being able to put the puzzle together peice by piece, you're forced to leave all the pieces you need scattered on the board, which brings me to the next biggest problem of the game: The koi pond.Surrounding the top left corners of the board is a koi pond where all of the peices of the puzzle reside. While being an interesting idea in theory, turned out to be this games biggest negative aspect. Again, lets think about how a real-life jigsaw puzzle works. When you're looking around at the countless peices you have to choose from, seeing which colors might match what you're trying to fit in, wouldn't it be great if all of those peices were constantly floating around in a sporadic, aimless fashion making it extremely frustrating to take the peice you want? No. No, that isn't great in the slightest. That isn't even the least of the koi pond issues. More often than not, you'll end up grabbing a piece you didn't mean to pick up, so you'll put it back down in the pond. Where does that peice go, you ask?  It reappears in a random spot in the pond. While this might not seem like that big of an issue, when you're trying to get the peice you need as it meshes in with all the other peices in the pond, if you pick it up and drop it accidentally it flys to a completely different location, further wasting your time. Not to mention there is a koi fish in the pond that you're able to pick up, which will often get in your way of picking up the pieces you want. This game just seems like a whole new species of headache inducing terror, which is a real shame because I really do enjoy the Japanese theme it was introducing, and I really do feel like it could have been great if they reworked those problems. There just needs to be another jigsaw puzzle game like the one from OMGpop.com a few years ago, it was a flawless jigsaw puzzle game that really embodied the experience of putting together a puzzle with your friends. But until then, I guess I'll have to check out Pixel Puzzles: Anime. God help me.

Posted: August 3, 2015
												The puzzles are great.  The idea of having the pieces floating in the river is great.  The IDEA of plucking the pieces out of the river like fish is great.  Actually trying to grab a piece out of the river is ridiculous.  You can click (literally) dozens of times on the piece you want and pick up instead some other piece every time.  In fact, the piece you actually get is usually no where near the piece you're clicking on.  Its a mess on higher level puzzles with more pieces.  It's maddening.  I can only imagine what a nightmare the last puzzle is going to be but I want to finish them all so ... :(

Posted: March 27, 2015
												I really do like this game, but it has some major bugs. Out of the 14 puzzles I have completed, I've had to restart three when I only had one piece left to place. I had to restart twice due to the final piece not fitting correctly. One needed to be rotated and the second time the piece shape needed to be flipped (the negative size needed to be on the right and the positive side needed to be on the left). The third time, there wasn't a final piece, the game somehow made one piece just disappear. I grabbed the fish a million times to try and see it if was stuck, searched the river and corners, I clicked all over the completed puzzle to make sure it wasn't just hidden on the board, but alas, it was nowhere. I also find it to be frustrating when trying to grab a specific piece and it grabs every single piece other than the one I have selected. I usually get around this by only selecting pieces that are on the top since they are not as crowded. I cannot recommend this to anyone who is a completionist, like me, due to the fact that sometimes you cant complete the puzzle unless you restart. I still purchased this despite a review saying they didn't recommend this, but it was less than a dollar. However, once I experienced these bugs, I found myself wondering how in the world something could be so badly designed that pieces dont fit/ are missing. Either way, I think this is a great idea and it is relaxing (until you experience said bugs). I just wish they would fix the bugs and then it will be a great, simple, and cheap game.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												So... What to say about 'Pixel Puzzles: Japan'... It's a puzzle game! No rotating blocks... No floating pills... No exploading candies, gems or animals... But an actual jigsaw puzzle game. Now if it were just that, my review would be done now, but there's more. The puzzles are lovely and are in various shapes, cuts and sizes.The goal of the game is simple... Complete a puzzle and obtain a golden puzzle piece for your monk so that he may ascend to a higher state... and ultimately, puzzles with more pieces. As you set about the task putting together the puzzles, the pieces not on the board yet, float around on the surface of a pond and you have to try and scoop up the piece you'd like. If you toss a piece back into the water, you can sink a number of pieces foor a moment in hopes of making it easier to grab the piece you do want... And that's it.It's a nice, simple and relaxing game, set to soothing oriental music; perfect for the casual gamer that enjoys a slow paced game or the hardcore garmer looking to find that calm before the storm of bullets and rampaging zombies... among other things.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												Althought I like puzzles and puzzle games, I cannot recommend this game based on two glaring issues.-No save feature: this is the big one. Not being able to save means you're stuck working on a puzzle or leaving it running in the background unless you want to start completely over.-Piece selection: 9 times out of 10, clicking on piece you need will make you pick up a different piece that is floating around near it. It's frustrating to say the least, and the later puzzles (200+ pieces) are almost impossible to finish without the stacking exploit because of this failure to point and click.If you're an achievement hunter, the 26 achievements aren't hard to earn, just very, very tedious. The game also drops 6 cards, but the are almost worthless on the market due to the free keys for this game given away recently.If a save feature was implemented and the piece selection fixed, I would recommend this game; until that time, save your money and your hours for something else. I haven't played anything else in the series so I do not know how they compare.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												It's all fun and games at the beginning and you wonder how is it even possible to screw up on a simple game like this. The puzzles are easy, not too many pieces, but then you get to the last ones and the flaws become apparent. You can't save your progress in the middle of a puzzle, you can't join pieces together out of the board, and, the worst of all, you can't get the piece you want because it's burrowed under thousands of others you don't want, and because every piece just decides to float wherever they want, there is no way to dig them out in time.Also, if you manage to stack every single piece, you always get them in the correct order from the top left to bottom right, so nice programming.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												Oh my word the design choices on this one. Sounds fun and mellow enough, just a classic fit the pieces together puzzle like your grandpa did on the table top. Your grandpa could always look at the box to see the picture, but I still can't seem to figure out how I made the picture pop up that one time. Then there are the absolutely tiny puzzle pieces floating in a pond. Floating all over each other, and generally being a nuisance to click, or find the one piece you want. I've had to click 10 times, randomly getting other nearby pieces, before finally getting the one I want. The pictures themselves are pretty, but several just don't have enough definition between areas of the puzzle. It turns them into a random "does this fit here?" mess of trial and error. Then I haven't found a way to save in the middle of a puzzle, you know like grandpa leaving it on the kitchen table til he can get around to it again. If you want to tell me how to save, or look up the puzzle, that's awesome, but it's something the game needs to explain in some clear way itself. Even better would be giving me some static place I can sort the damn puzzle pieces, without just tossing all of them on the puzzle board, where some will obviously randomly click into the right place. That's not how I want the game to work.In short, something seemingly meant to be soothing is for me entirely aggravating.2/5

Posted: February 15
												The puzzles themselves are decent, but unfortunately there are a couple of bad design choice compounded by a game-breaking bug that makes the game more frustrating than fun. See, all of your puzzle pieces are floating around in a koi pon moving around. This already makes it hard to grab the pieces you want, or even find them when there are hundreds of pieces. If you want to stop the pieces from moving, the only place to put pieces that aren't properly set in the puzzle is on the puzzle board itself, which can be very cluttering. But when you select any pieces at all, whether to put it in its final place or just on the board in a pile, it's almost impossible to select the right one. This is partially because the pieces are all moving about, but there's actually a bug that almost always prevents you from selecting the piece you want even when you definitely click on it directly. This makes grabbing any piece an exercise in futility unless you literally take every single piece and make a big pile on the board to sort out there. And all of this is made worse by the lack of any mid-puzzle saving feature at all, so you can only do puzzles in one playthrough, which just seems like a bad choice to me. The game would be improved if these problems were fixed, but there's been no move by the developers to try to fix the bug or add a save option. From what I understand the bug actually stems from an issue with the game engine, and later puzzle games of theirs use a newer engine and don't have the same problem, so they should be fine, but it's just not worth picking this one up unless you want to be annoyed by constant misclicks.

Posted: August 4, 2015
												"Pixel Puzzles: Japan" is what you would expect from a puzzle game, except for some mismatches in the programming neclecting to some extend the variety of reality puzzles and score lines such as time tables as well as Multiplayer competition. To start with statistics, they simply do not exist, though it would be wishful to see at least your best time and perhaps a score line corresponding to weight functions of the puzzle parts.  Another missing is Multiplayer Mode, and of course, one can easily imagine how attractive this gane could become with such an institution installed in accordance to the standards.The reality comparision may not be totally appropriate, but it's noteworthy to recognize that you cannot rotate the puzzle parts, i.e. they are always preset to insert. An additional rotation (the function of the right mouse button is not in use in this game), perhaps combined with an additional difficulty level (there is only one level explicitly given), would surely make this game more interesting.So, then, after explaining the need of some expansion pack to justify the price (at the moment 70% off would do), what is positive about this game? Answer: It's the shaping of the puzzle parts combined with the variety of motifs, which evoke different strategies of solvation. Thereby, strategies can be chosen according to the color (motif) and the shape of the puzzle parts, especially orientated towards the border parts of the puzzle. Together with the number of puzzle parts, these three ingredients, as functions of the motif, determine a certain level of difficulty. For example, a temple of 112 parts with clear shaped lines and strict color changes could be said to be of an easier handling than a picture of a Sakura branch of 250 parts, where you are left alone with the almost one colored Sakura blossoms. Therefore, the need of concentration in solving a puzzle applying some sorts of strategy makes it clear that this game can be of some interest, generally speaking.

Posted: February 19
												This is a very relaxing puzzle game. I haven't enjoyed a puzzle game in a long time. The sound becomes a bit anoying but there is an option in the setting to mute it. Sometimes it's a bit hard to get the piece you click on, which means it will give you a complete different piece than you have focused on, but if you really like puzzle games, you get used to it after a while.Also on the hardest difficulty i recommend to change the background colour to see the pieces better.

Posted: February 15
												The puzzles themselves are decent, but unfortunately there are a couple of bad design choice compounded by a game-breaking bug that makes the game more frustrating than fun. See, all of your puzzle pieces are floating around in a koi pon moving around. This already makes it hard to grab the pieces you want, or even find them when there are hundreds of pieces. If you want to stop the pieces from moving, the only place to put pieces that aren't properly set in the puzzle is on the puzzle board itself, which can be very cluttering. But when you select any pieces at all, whether to put it in its final place or just on the board in a pile, it's almost impossible to select the right one. This is partially because the pieces are all moving about, but there's actually a bug that almost always prevents you from selecting the piece you want even when you definitely click on it directly. This makes grabbing any piece an exercise in futility unless you literally take every single piece and make a big pile on the board to sort out there. And all of this is made worse by the lack of any mid-puzzle saving feature at all, so you can only do puzzles in one playthrough, which just seems like a bad choice to me. The game would be improved if these problems were fixed, but there's been no move by the developers to try to fix the bug or add a save option. From what I understand the bug actually stems from an issue with the game engine, and later puzzle games of theirs use a newer engine and don't have the same problem, so they should be fine, but it's just not worth picking this one up unless you want to be annoyed by constant misclicks.

Posted: February 9
												In the real world I don’t like puzzles as it's too hard to keep my dog from eating them. If I turn my back for one second he’s on the table chowing down on the pieces!(Or I accidentally lose pieces in some other less entertaining way)Fortunately my dog can’t interfere with a computer game, and that’s part of what makes Pixel Puzzles: Japan so great. The worst thing that happens on the computer is that you grab a fish!On a more serious note, the pictures are beautiful and the puzzles are reasonably entertaining. I really like that the pieces lock into the correct locations preventing you from accidentally moving them and hurting your progress. The one potential drawback is that the pieces are locked into the proper orientation. This means its essentially doing puzzles on easy mode. This doesn't bother me, but puzzle experts may want to look elsewhere for more challenge.Pixel Puzzles: Japan renewed my interest in puzzles. I definitely recommend it.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												It's a simple puzzle game. Nothing more, but also nothing less!The images are nice and assembling the tiles is just relaxing. Just fire it up when you need to calm down and want to let your mind wander. A minor grievance is that picking up the tiles in the water is sometime not as precise as you want it to be and you end up picking the wrong tile 3 times in a row.If you are looking for some easy achievements, this game provides 26 of them. Just play through the game and earn all of them without hassle.Especially on sale it is really worth the price. For the regular price it might be close call, but if you get it on sale (currently 85% off), you can't go wrong!

Posted: March 22, 2015
IntroductionAn effective jigsaw puzzle game with satisfying goals, and a decent reward and progression system to underpin the overall experience.MechanicsSuccessfully blends puzzle game mechanics with a hint system, lending the whole game to feel well thought out and implemented. Controls and UI are snappy and responsive.GraphicsA decent selection of original art is included for each puzzle, and the menus and UI are integrated nicely with the art direction.SoundThe sounds are effective, with each interaction on the board, and with the pieces, featuring satisfying sounds to complement the experience.ConclusionAs one of the first jigsaw puzzle games on Steam, literally any game would have been effective. Luckily, Pixel Puzzles is better than average, and if you're looking for a decent puzzle game to remember, I can recommend this game.
